Titular: Chipotle boosts outlook after strong sales growth in second quarter
Texto: Chipotle Mexican Grill bumped up its outlook for a key sales revenue metric, following forecast-beating revenue and adjusted earnings during the second quarter.That countered some of the concern around a rising food, beverage and packaging costs, and helped push shares 4 per cent higher in after-hours trade on Tuesday to a record high.The fast casual restaurant chain said it now expected comparable restaurant sales — a closely watched industry metric — to increase by the high single-digits percentage compared with a year ago. That was up from their previous forecast for growth in the mid- to high-single-digit range.Comparable sales, which are for outlets open at least 13 months, in the quarter ended June 30 rose 10 per cent from a year ago, and drove an overall 13.2 per cent year-on-year increase in group revenue to $1.43bn. That was ahead of the median forecast for $1.4bn in a survey of analysts by Refinitiv.Brian Niccol, chief executive, said this was the sixth consecutive quarter of accelerating comparable sales growth. “These strong results were delivered despite a tougher year over year comparison and benefited from better restaurant operations, more effective marketing, and leveraging our digital make line to grow sales and expand access”, he added.Reported earnings almost doubled to $3.22 a diluted share from a year ago, but were weighed down by a 77 cent after-tax impact from expenses related to restaurant asset impairment and corporate restructuring.On an adjusted basis, earnings of $3.99 a share were up from $2.87 a year ago and came in ahead of Wall Street estimates for $3.76.Chipotle said its food, beverage and packaging costs, rose 1.1 percentage points from a year ago to represent 33.7 per cent of revenue. That was primarily due to the increased cost of avocados and, to a lesser extent, increased dairy costs, although these were partially offset by menu price increases that were rolled out countrywide at the end of last year.Shares were up 4 per cent in after-hours trade at $769.18, a record high.

Titular: US food and restaurant chains hit by rising pork prices
Subtitular: Chipotle shares among those affected as African swine fever prompts hog cull
Texto: A disease ravaging hog farms 11,000km away in China is affecting US restaurant chains and meat producers, leaving customers forking over higher prices for their pork.Hormel Foods, which produces Spam, said on Thursday that African swine fever in China drove up pork costs, weighing on its quarterly earnings and contributing to a cut in its full-year earnings and sales outlook.Meanwhile shares in Chipotle Mexican Grill came under pressure after analysts at BMO Capital Markets issued the equivalent of a sell rating for the stock, warning that surging pork prices will eat into the restaurant chain’s bottom line.Minnesota-based Hormel, whose brands also include Jenny-O Turkey and Justin’s peanut butter, reported record sales in its latest quarter but chief executive Jim Snee said: “As we look forward, the biggest unknown in the protein industry is related to the outbreak of African swine fever in China.”African swine fever is a highly contagious and deadly viral disease that affects both domestic and wild pigs. On its earnings call, Hormel pointed to industry information that showed China, the world’s largest pork producer and consumer, has lost 150m to 200m hogs, equivalent to more than the entire pork production in the US.Hog prices jumped nearly 20 per cent in China in the second quarter, and Hormel said it expects prices to continue to rise as cold storage stocks are drawn.The considerable decline in China’s pig population has driven US lean hog prices up 46 per cent since the start of the year, after declining 15 per cent in 2018.BMO analyst Andrew Strelzik said among the restaurants within his coverage, Chipotle is the most vulnerable to swings in pork prices. He forecast that Chipotle could begin to see the effect as early as the third quarter, and the impact “could be far greater” than current estimates.The bank downgraded Chipotle’s stock to underperform from market-perform and cut its price target to $620 from $675.“We believe the potential magnitude and duration of [African swine fever] impacts to margins is under-appreciated and [Chipotle] is among the restaurants most at risk,” Mr Strelzik wrote in a note to clients.Chipotle’s shares dropped 5.4 per cent to $667.33 in afternoon trading. The stock had been up more than 60 per cent year to date, thanks to a run of strong sales growth.Hormel shares fell 1.4 per cent to $38.94. Texas Roadhouse and Outback Steakhouse owner Bloomin’ Brands, two other chains with notable pork exposure, tumbled 4.4 per cent and 9.4 per cent, respectively.Hormel’s Mr Snee also noted that trade wars were contributing to price pressure. “The key driver to the decline [in international sales] continues to be lower fresh pork exports volume and pricing caused by global trade uncertainty related to tariffs,” he said.

Titular: Chipotle shares fall on new subpoena over food safety
Subtitular: Restaurant chain faces request related to illness outbreak in Ohio last year
Texto: Chipotle Mexican Grill shares fell on Thursday after the restaurant chain disclosed a new subpoena it received over the outbreak of a foodborne illness at one of its stores last year.The Denver-based company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it received a subpoena on April 18 requesting information related to outbreaks at multiple locations, including a restaurant in Powell, Ohio, where hundreds of customers got sick last summer. The other locations — stores in Simi Valley, California; Boston, Massachusetts; Sterling, Virginia; and Los Angeles, California — were also covered under previous subpoenas from the US District Court for the Central District of California.The subpoenas are related to a criminal investigation by the US attorney’s office and the Food and Drug Administration.“Food safety is our number one priority at Chipotle. We have been co-operating and meeting with the government over the last several years and have been providing them with information regarding our food safety standards, which we believe leads the food service industry. The subpoena that we received is part of the government’s ongoing investigation and we are continuing to co-operate fully,” the company said in a statement.Chipotle confirmed in August that bacteria sickened customers who ate food prepared at the Ohio restaurant. It was the latest food safety incident to plague Chipotle, which dealt with a widespread E. coli outbreak in late 2015 and early 2016 that scared off customers.Shares were down 4.3 per cent on Thursday. However, the stock remains 57 per cent higher so far this year amid improving sales trends at the fast-casual chain.Chipotle reported better first-quarter earnings and revenue than expected and boosted its guidance for comparable sales on Wednesday, saying digital orders continue to drive growth. Under chief executive Brian Niccol, Chipotle has expanded online ordering and delivery and experimented with new menu items to win back diners. The company has also run advertisements highlighting its use of fresh ingredients.

Titular: Chipotle raises sales view as online orders double
Texto: Chipotle Mexican Grill bumped up its expectations for full-year sales after the company’s first-quarter results outpaced forecasts, aided by online orders that doubled.The fast-casual restaurant chain, purveyor of tacos and burrito bowls, on Wednesday forecast mid- to high-single digit growth in comparable restaurant sales in 2019, compared with analysts’ average estimate of 5.8 per cent. Chipotle previously expected to post an increase in the mid-single digit percentage range.It continues to plan on opening between 140 and 155 new restaurants this year.“The ongoing improvement in each of our key operating metrics over the past few quarters gives us confidence that our mission to win today and cultivate the future, is resonating,” Brian Niccol, chief executive of Chipotle, said in a statement.Chipotle’s sales suffered from a string of food-safety incidents dating back to 2015 that scared off customers. Mr Niccol, the former head of Yum Brands’ Taco Bell who joined Chipotle one year ago, has sought to revitalise the brand by expanding its menu, investing in online ordering and delivery and running advertisements focused on the use of fresh ingredients.Mr Niccol’s strategy has won over investors. Shares in Chipotle have been on fire, surging 65 per cent on the year after a 49.4 per cent rally in 2018. The stock was up 0.3 per cent in after-hours trading on Wednesday.In the March quarter, Chipotle registered a 9.9 per cent increase in comparable restaurant sales, its fifth consecutive period of accelerated growth and better than the 7.29 per cent gain expected by analysts.Revenue jumped 13.9 per cent to $1.3bn. Digital sales, which doubled year-over-year, accounted for 15.7 per cent of overall sales during the quarter.Chipotle earned net income of $88.1m, or $3.13 a share, up from $59.4m, or $2.13 a share, in the same quarter a year earlier. Excluding restructuring costs and other one-time charges, adjusted earnings per share of $3.40 handily beat analysts’ estimate of $3.01.

Titular: Online order surge fires up Chipotle sales
Subtitular: Shares rallied 10 per cent in late trading
Texto: Chipotle Mexican Grill handily beat expectations for quarterly sales and earnings amid a surge in digital orders, heating up shares late Wednesday.The fast-casual restaurant chain, known for its burrito bowls, said comparable sales jumped 6.1 per cent year-over-year in the December quarter. That was stronger than the 4.5 per cent increase projected by analysts, according to a Refinitiv poll, and included 2 per cent growth in transactions.Digital sales were up 65.6 per cent, accounting for 12.9 per cent of all sales.For 2019, Chipotle said it expects comparable sales at stores open at least 13 months — a closely watched industry metric — to grow in the mid-single digit range, compared with analysts’ average forecast of a 4.4 per cent improvement. The company also plans to open between 140 and 155 new restaurants.“The growth acceleration this quarter gives us confidence that our strategy is working,” chief executive Brian Niccol said in a statement. “When we connect with guests through great operations, relevant marketing focused on Chipotle’s great taste and real ingredients, and provide more convenient access, they respond enthusiastically.”Chipotle has sought to win back customers after a string of food-safety incidents, including a widespread E. coli outbreak in late 2015. Under Mr Niccol, the former head of Yum Brands’ Taco Bell who took the reins in March 2018, Chipotle has invested in online ordering and delivery, new menu items and a national marketing campaign that highlights the use of fresh ingredients.The stock has recovered in the past year to hit a three-year high of $543.90 on January 25. Shares rallied 9.6 per cent to $576.70 after the closing bell on Wednesday.California-based Chipotle booked $1.23bn in revenue during the fourth quarter, up 10.4 per cent against the same period a year earlier. The company opened 40 new stores and closed or relocated 12 others, bringing its total restaurant count to 2,491.Food, beverage and packaging costs were 33.2 per cent of revenue, a decline of 100 basis points driven by menu price increases and favourable avocado pricing.Net income was $32m, or $1.15 a share, down from $43.8m, or $1.55 a share, in the year-ago quarter. On an adjusted basis, earnings per share rose to $1.72 from $1.55.Analysts were looking for adjusted earnings of $1.37 a share on revenue of $1.19bn.Chipotle’s board approved up to $100m in additional share buybacks, adding to the current $57.6m under the previous repurchase program.

Titular: Chipotle falls to bottom of S&P 500 after analyst downgrade
Texto: Questions about Chipotle’s turnround efforts prompted Wedbush analysts to downgrade the fast-casual burrito chain on Monday, sending the company to the bottom of the S&P 500.Chipotle was down more than 4 per cent by midday, after Wedbush moved the stock from neutral to underperform, citing risk to near-term same-store sales and margin expectations.Chipotle investors have been optimistic that newly installed chief executive Brian Niccol would right the ship after joining from Taco Bell. That has helped Chipotle’s stock price climb back after years of tepid growth that followed a number of health crises.Just two weeks ago, Morgan Stanley raised Chipotle from equal weight to overweight, which sent shares skyward.But Wedbush said that the burrito chain’s same-store sales growth numbers are trending below expectations after a food poisoning outbreak in Ohio led the company to temporarily shut down one of its locations and retrain its employees nationwide on “food safety and wellness protocols,” according to a note from Mr Niccol posted to the Chipotle website.“We view the prospect of ongoing negative headlines from future outbreaks, even if relatively contained, as more likely,” say the analysts, while also expressing concern that Chipotle’s planned “product innovations” may fail to materialise as expected.Even with Monday’s decline, however, Chipotle’s stock is still up by more than 72 per cent for the year.

Titular: Chipotle’s comeback hopes spur Morgan Stanley upgrade
Texto: Investors are digging into Chipotle on Wednesday, sending the fast-casual burrito chain’s shares to a two-and-a-half year high after receiving an upgrade from Morgan Stanley in hopes that its turnround is off to a solid start.Morgan Stanley raised its rating on Chipotle from equal weight to overweight with a price target of $600, up from $413 previously. The vote of confidence pushed shares up 4.38 per cent to $514.94.When it first went public, Chipotle’s popularity made it a hot property, but the momentum came to a screeching halt in 2015, when it was rattled by a food-safety scare. Attempts to juice growth with new menu items and marketing initiatives largely fell flat, leaving growth to stagnate.Earlier this year, the company named Brian Niccol, the chief executive of Mexican fast-food chain Taco Bell, to replace founder Steve Ells as its new chief executive. That whetted Wall Street’s appetite, given the strides Taco Bell made under Mr Niccols to generate buzz with coveted millennial consumers.Mr Niccol has laid out an ambitious plan to put the sizzle back into Chipotle sales — including efforts to become more “culturally relevant”, building up digital offerings and forging deeper ties to customers through a new loyalty programme.While it is still “early days”, Morgan Stanley analyst John Glass said that he saw “increasing evidence” that Chipotle may have come across a recipe for success — including the management change and plenty of “low hanging opportunities” to boost sales through marketing, product development and operational improvements.“The scarcity of growth stocks across consumer discretionary could also increase investors’ willingness to pay a high multiple for an early innings recovery story, while the narrative of new management with sales levers to pull is one that has typically worked in restaurants,” he wrote.Still, he noted that there was a risk that turnround hopes could be running too hot — especially given its reliance on consumer discretionary spending remaining strong and the lingering threat that another food-safety problem could derail its progress.Chipotle shares rose nearly 5 per cent to $517.55 on Wednesday, their highest since March 2016, according to Thomson Reuters data. So far this year, they have advanced nearly 80 per cent, after three consecutive years in which they lost more than 20 per cent of their value.

Titular: Chipotle results top market forecasts as turnround bears fruit
Texto: Chipotle’s new chief executive is already seeing signs of a recovery at the fast-casual burrito chain after it reported quarterly sales and earnings that cruised past analysts’ forecasts. Revenue at the Denver-based fast-casual burrito chain rose 8.3 per cent from a year ago to $1.3bn in the three months ended June 30, thanks in part to the opening of a net 26 restaurants during the quarter. That topped the average of $1.26bn from analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters.Net income was $46.9m, or $1.68 a diluted share, and included $33.4m in expenses related to restructuring charges. Adjusted earnings of $2.87 a share were up 23.7 per cent from a year ago and were 7 cents ahead of market forecasts.Chipotle in February appointed Brian Niccol, who previously led Mexican food chain Taco Bell, as its new chief executive. Investors have been optimistic that Mr Niccol can transplant his success reviving the fortunes of Taco Bell at Chipotle, which had suffered several years of lacklustre sales following a food-safety crisis in 2015.Mr Niccol then brought over former colleague Chris Brandt, who oversaw some of the initiatives that made Taco Bell popular with millennials, to be Chipotle’s chief marketing officer.Mr Niccol said in a statement he was pleased with sales and restaurant margins coming in ahead of expectations during the second quarter. “While we made progress during the quarter with particular strength in digital sales, I firmly believe we can accelerate that progress by executing our reorganisation and our strategy to win today and cultivate tomorrow.”Chipotle shares were up 5 per cent cent in after-hours trade on Thursday. The stock is up about 55 per cent in 2018, having fallen by more than 20 per cent in each of the past three calendar years.

Titular: Chipotle plans some belt-tightening to beef up growth
Texto: Chipotle executives warned investors of some short-term hiccups — including the closure of up to 60 underperforming stores and a restructuring charge of as much as $135m — as the fast-casual burrito chain tries to transform into a leaner, meaner company under its new chief executive, Brian Niccol.During a call on Wednesday, Mr Niccol — who joined the company from fast-food chain Taco Bell earlier this year — and other executives laid out their strategies for trying to put the sizzle back into Chipotle after several years of lacklustre sales following a damaging food-safety crisis.Mr Niccol focused on three key initiatives: revamping its marketing and communication strategies to become more “culturally relevant”, including new menu items, building up its digital offerings, and forging deeper ties to customers with a new loyalty programme, set to launch in 2019.“I can easily see a future where Chipotle more than doubles the business to $10 billion in revenue,” Mr Niccol said. “We will execute flawlessly in our existing restaurants, add more high-performing restaurants, build brand relevance and engagement, expand digital capabilities for team members and customers, and build an organisation with top tier talent that can win today and cultivate a better future.”Part of that transformation will involve some slimming down, executives said. Chipotle is planning to close between 55 and 60 underperforming locations — including five of its Pizzeria Locale restaurants outside of Denver — and expects to take a restructuring charge between $115m and $135m.Investors’ appetites have been whetted by the arrival of Mr Niccol, who was seen as key to the success Taco Bell has had in recent years in engaging with millennials and exciting customers with unusual menu items. The first earnings report released after his arrival unleashed a wave of enthusiasm, driving Chipotle shares to a record one-day gain on optimism that he will be able to cook up similar results at his new company.On Wednesday’s call, Mr Niccol assured investors that “the underlying sales trends that we are seeing as the sales trends from Q1 have continued into Q2.”But investors seemingly found less to sink their teeth into than they had expected during Wednesday’s call. Chipotle shares dropped more than 3 per cent in after-hours trading.After falling 23.4 per cent in 2017, Chipotle shares are up 58.2 per cent so far in 2018, still making them one of the top performers in the S&P 500.

Titular: Callout to legal sector: join us to tackle Covid-19 problems
Subtitular: Hackathon will develop answers to a range of challenges faced by business, governments and society
Texto: A global hackathon supported by the Financial Times is inviting organisations and individuals in the legal sector to develop solutions to problems created by the coronavirus pandemic.The FT Innovative Lawyers reports have over the past 15 years recognised innovators from across the global legal sector for their skills in solving complex problems for business and society. Now we are asking these innovators to help tackle some of the urgent challenges posed by Covid-19. The deadline to register as a participant or to suggest a challenge is April 26.Organised by Global Legal Hackathon (GLH), and supported by FT Innovative Lawyers, the hackathon will take place online from April 27 to May 17. It will bring together legal professionals, software developers, designers and businesspeople to develop solutions to problems identified by organisations, governments, and individuals.Organisations of any type are invited to submit challenges, which can relate to their business, industry, staff, clients, communities, their country, or the world. Participants in the hackathon will then form teams to address challenges which might range from the online functioning of courts to helping migrant workers caught in lockdown limbo.The overall objective is to harness the collective capability, energy and innovation of the world’s legal industry to support communities, governments and industries during this global emergency.A hackathon traditionally involves teams of professionals, software developers, designers and other experts working intensely over short periods of time to build prototype software solutions. The FT Innovative Lawyers-Global Legal Hackathon Challenge will seek to solve a range of legal and related challenges through technology or other means. It will be held online over three weeks.We are inviting all law firms, company legal teams, law companies, legal technology companies, public sector and non-profit organisations to get involved in one or more of the following ways:Individuals working in the legal industry, public sector and non-profit organisations, or who are studying in the law can get involved in one or both of the following ways:We welcome ideas from now for challenges from any public, private or non-profit organisation. The challenges will be published prior to the start of the hackathon on April 27 on the FTIL-GLH website here.Challenges can be submitted directly by registering online here. You will need to provide the following details:- Name and short description of the problem to be solved- Relevant background, including key potential stakeholders/beneficiaries- Scope of the challenge: for a business, organisation, government, community, industry, country, region or global remit- Your contact details- Whether you intend to be named or remain anonymous as the challenge contributorIndividual participants and teams can register to participate in the hackathon here.Once registered, participants will be able to found a project related to one of the listed challenges, or request to join another project team via the FTIL-GLH website.Global Legal Hackathon will provide participants with access to business and technical tutorials, guides, and training resources on how to develop and present solutions, and how to collaborate remotely, prior to the event.To find full conditions for participation in the hackathon, please read Global Legal Hackathon’s terms and conditions on the FTIL-GLH website.Deadline to contribute a challenge to the hackathon: April 26, 2020 via a form here.Deadline to register to participate in the hackathon: April 26, 2020 via the registration form here.The hackathon goes live: The hackathon will run from April 27 to May 17. Teams can spend any amount of time during this period to collaborate and develop their project solutions.Presentation of solutions: On or before May 17 2020, teams should submit a five minute or less video presentation of their solution, a pitch deck, and/or links to software or applications that have been developed.The chance to be showcased in the Financial Times: A selection of solutions developed during the hackathon will be showcased on FT.com in June. This will include case studies and summaries written by FT journalists and RSG Consulting.Contact detailsFor questions about the hackathon please contact RSG Consulting on +44 (0)20 7831 0300, ftresearch@rsgconsulting.com.To find full conditions for participation in the hackathon, please read Global Legal Hackathon’s terms and conditions on the FTIL-GLH website.The FT and RSG Consulting reserve the right to decide which challenges are published and which solutions are showcased in the FT.The FT reserves the right to cancel, postpone or suspend its participation in the FT Innovative Lawyers-Global Legal Hackathon Challenge at any time.

Titular: Chipotle to move headquarters to California
Texto: The changes keep coming at Chipotle. Just months after it named a new chief executive, the fast-casual burrito chain said on Wednesday that it will move its headquarters from Denver, Colorado — where its first restaurant was opened 25 years ago — to Newport Beach, California, as it ploughs ahead with efforts to make a clean break from recent woes.Chipotle said that over the next six months, it will move operations from its current Denver office to either Newport Beach or another office in Columbus, Ohio, which houses support functions. It will also transition functions from its offices in New York to one of those two locations. About 400 employees will be affected, Chipotle said.Brian Niccol, the former Taco Bell executive who took over as chief executive earlier this year from founder Steve Ells, said:“We have a tremendous opportunity at Chipotle to shape the future of our organisation and drive growth through our new strategy. In order to align the structure around our strategic priorities, we are transforming our culture and building world-class teams to revitalise the brand and enable our long-term success.”Mr Niccol’s arrival has fed hopes that Chipotle was finally turning the page on a food-safety crisis that rattled it in 2015. It was subsequently plagued by lacklustre growth, but investors are now pinning their hopes on Mr Niccol’s ability to transform Chipotle and boost its popularity like he did at Taco Bell.

Titular: Chipotle shares serve up $239m one-day gain for Ackman
Subtitular: Mexican fast-food chain’s new boss, Brian Niccol, wows Wall Street on debut
Texto: Bill Ackman’s Pershing Square made almost a quarter of a billion dollars on its stake in Chipotle on Thursday, as shares in the burrito chain soared by 24 per cent.Chipotle’s stock made its largest-ever one day gain on Thursday, after its first earnings report under a new chief executive injected optimism that the beleaguered chain may finally be turning a corner. Pershing Square, Mr Ackman’s investment group, is Chipotle’s largest shareholder, with 2.9m shares, or 10.3 per cent of the company, according to regulatory filings. The value of its stake jumped $239m to $1.2bn as Chipotle shares rose $82.98 to $422.50.Thursday’s rise only takes the shares back to around the level at which they were trading in September 2016 when Pershing Square first disclosed a big stake, however.After coming under pressure from investors including Mr Ackman, the company replaced founder Steve Ells as chief executive in February this year. To lead its turnround, it brought in a respected veteran of fast food, Brian Niccol.On his debut earnings call with analysts, Mr Niccol spoke of his ambitions to make Chipotle’s brand “much more visible”.We have a lot of work ahead of us, but I’m optimisticIn the coming months, he said, “you will see us piloting various tests” in areas such as online ordering, marketing spending and menu tweaks. He also cited “simple pivots” the company is already making, such as advertising that highlights locally-sourced ingredients.“I do want to acknowledge that there’s a lot of great work under way and we are starting to get some traction,” he said. “We have a lot of work ahead of us, but I’m optimistic.”While light on details, investors and analysts welcomed the comments and Mr Niccol repeatedly promised to share more on a “special call” before the next quarterly results.“We found the CEO enthusiasm contagious,” said Jeffrey Bernstein, analyst at Barclays. “With a new CEO for the first time in the 25-year brand history, it was not surprising that CEO commentary overshadowed [quarterly results].”However, Mr Bernstein warned “execution will prove more difficult” and that the plans appear to be “more evolution than revolution”.While Chipotle helped pioneer the trend of “fast-casual” dining, the company’s reputation has been bruised in recent years by incidents ranging from food safety scares to rising avocado prices to rats falling from the ceiling in restaurants. Since then, efforts to win back customers have largely fallen flat. Mr Niccol had previously led Yum Brands’ Taco Bell chain and was credited with reviving that Mexican fast-food chain’s popularity with millennials, thanks to clever marketing and new menu items. Chipotle’s shares are up 46 per cent this year, after registering double-digit percentage declines each year from 2015 and 2017, as it struggled to bounce back from a food-safety crisis.In the three months to the end of March, Chipotle’s comparable sales rose 2.2 per cent, outpacing analyst forecasts for a 1.3 per cent increase. Operating costs, including food, fell. A slew of analysts upgraded their price targets for Chipotle after the results and the comments from Mr Niccol. “While 1Q results were only slightly better than expected, we are more intrigued by the potential for brand improvement under new CEO Brian Niccol,” said David Palmer with RBC, who raised his price target for Chipotle shares to $360, from $340. Andy Barish, an analyst with Jefferies, raised his price target from $300 to $350, explaining that “we believe turn is in early stages with new CEO Brian Niccol’s strategies . . . possibly helping later in the year”.

Titular: Chipotle eyes best day on record as new chief feeds turnround hopes
Texto: Order up at Chipotle. The fast-casual burrito chain is cruising towards its best-ever one-day gain after its first earnings report under new chief executive Brian Niccol unleashed a wave of optimism about its prospects of finally turning a corner from the food-safety crisis that has dogged it.The company’s shares zoomed 24.3 per cent higher on Thursday to $422.13 following the report, putting them on track for their biggest one-day advance since going public in 2006.For Chipotle, it’s a welcome break from the bruising it has taken in recent years as the food-safety scare dented its momentum, and efforts to spice up its offerings and lure back customers largely fell short.To help jump-start those efforts, founder Steve Ells agreed last year to step aside from his role as chief executive (while staying on as executive chairman) and in February, Brian Niccol – who led Yum Brands’ fast-food Mexican chain Taco Bell – was named as his successor.Mr Niccol has only spent a little over a month in the top job, but Chipotle’s earnings from the first three months of 2018 indicate that there is some momentum for him to build off of as he moves to put his mark on the chain, with sales growing and operating costs, including food, falling.In his subsequent call with investors, Mr Niccol – who garnered a reputation for menu innovation and smart marketing during his time at Taco Bell – said he will lay out details of his strategic plan before its next earnings announcement. In the meantime, he said that Chipotle will focus in the short term on making “simple pivots” to help boost the brand’s appeal, like tweaking menu items and advertising.That message resonated with analysts, who delivered a slew of upgrades to their ratings and price targets on the company.One of those upgrades came from BTIG, which switched its rating from “neutral” to “buy” with a $460 price target. Analyst Peter Saleh wrote:“We expect the recent change in leadership will bring some fresh perspective, generate efficiencies within the restaurants and drive much needed innovation. While management indicated more clarity on strategy changes will be discussed in the coming months, we believe Chipotle could see material improvements in marketing, innovation and digital access. Given the earnings potential from a stronger sales and margin recovery, we are inclined to get ahead of this prospect rather than wait and are upgrading shares accordingly.”After falling by more than 20 per cent each year since 2015, Chipotle shares are up 46.1 per cent so far in 2018, including Thursday’s gain.

Titular: Chipotle earnings whet Wall Street’s appetite
Texto: Chipotle’s first quarterly report under new chief executive Brian Niccol has given investors something to sink their teeth into, and the fast-casual burrito chain’s shares heated up in after-hours trading following better than expected earnings.The company’s shares rose more than 10 per cent on Wednesday evening on the results, which fuelled Wall Street hopes Chipotle may finally be turning a corner from the food-safety crisis in 2015 that has weighed on it.For the three months ended March 31, revenue grew 7.4 per cent year-on-year to $1.1bn. Comparable sales, a key industry metric, rose 2.2 per cent, with recent price increases helping to offset fewer transactions.Net income was up to $59.4m from $46.1m in the year-ago period, while earnings per share rose 33.1 per cent year-over-year to $2.13. Food costs fell 140 basis points from a year ago to represent 32.4 per cent of revenue, with menu price hikes and lower paper usage helping to offset the higher costs of its switch to preservative-free tortillas.Analysts had been looking for $44m in net income, or $1.58 a share, on sales of $1.14bn, according to Factset. Same-store sales had been pegged to rise 1.3 per cent.The results are the first since February’s announcement that Mr Niccol, the one-time chief executive of Yum Brands’ Mexican fast-food chain Taco Bell, took over Chipotle’s top job, replacing founder Steve Ells, who said last year he will be stepping back — though he will remain executive chairman. Investors cheered the news, as Mr Niccol was seen as a driving force behind Taco Bell’s recently resurgence in popularity, especially among millennials.The company’s shares are up 17.5 per cent this year, after registering double-digit percentage declines each year from 2015 and 2017, as it struggled to bounce back from a food-safety crisis that spooked customers. In addition to the new chief executive, Chipotle bagged another Taco Bell alum, Chris Brandt, last month to replace its outgoing chief marketing officer.Mr Niccol said:“While the company made notable progress during the quarter, I firmly believe we can accelerate that progress in the future. We are in the process of forming a path to greater performance in sales, transactions, margins and new restaurants. This path to performance will be grounded in a strategy of executing the fundamentals while introducing consumer-meaningful innovation across the business. It will also require a structure and organisation built for creativity, action and accountability. Finally, Chipotle will have a culture that is centred on running great restaurants, putting the customer first, innovating for today and tomorrow, supporting each other, and delivering on commitments. The future will be meaningful at Chipotle.”

Titular: Chipotle bags another ex-Taco Bell exec in turnround bid
Texto: Chipotle has bagged itself another Taco Bell alum to help spice up its turnround efforts.The fast-casual burrito chain said on Tuesday that it had hired Chris Brandt to replace its outgoing chief marketing officer.Mr Brandt will join Chipotle on April 2, reporting to Brian Niccol, the new chief executive who recently left Mexican fast-food chain Taco Bell to lead the company’s efforts to revive its fortunes.Mr Brandt also has Taco Bell on his resume, having served as chief brand and marketing officer at the Yum Brands subsidiary, before joining Bloomin’ Brands, the parent company of casual dining chains including Outback Steakhouse.While at Taco Bell, Mr Brandt helped oversee some of the initiatives that have boosted the taco chain popularity with millennials, including the Taco Bell app and attention-grabbing, unconventional menu items like the Doritos Locos Tacos and the quesalupa.Mr Niccol said in a statement:“Chris is an extremely talented and effective marketing executive. Having worked with Chris in the past, I have seen first-hand his ability to generate sales overnight and build brands over time. His experience and expertise make him an ideal fit for our leadership team at Chipotle as we look to reinvigorate this exceptional brand, and build sales, transactions and profitability.”The executive shake-up at Chipotle comes as the company attempts to turn the page on a damaging food-safety crisis. Its recent efforts to re-whet customers’ appetites by launching new menu items like queso dip have landed with a thud, however, and Chipotle’s founder, Steve Ells, said he would step aside from the chief executive position once a replacement was found.Chipotle shares are up 1.5 per cent in midday trading on Tuesday to $321.70, and have advanced 11.3 per cent so far in 2018 after falling 23.4 per cent in 2017.

Titular: Chipotle eyes best day in nearly 5 years after nabbing Taco Bell CEO
Texto: It’s a mouth-watering combination – Chipotle, the fast-casual burrito chain, has tapped the chief of Mexican fast-food brand Taco Bell to help turn a corner on stagnant sales and a food safety crisis, and the initial rush of enthusiasm has sent its shares on course for their best single-day advance in almost five years.Chipotle shares were up nearly 15 per cent on Wednesday to $288.51, a day after it made the long-expected announcement of who will replace founder Steve Ells as chief executive. Brian Niccol will be joining the Denver-based company from Taco Bell, the Yum Brands fast-food chain where he has held leadership roles since 2011.Mr Niccol has been credited with helping to turn around Taco Bell, which has been exciting younger consumers through creative marketing and social media that promotes novel menu items like the Doritos Taco Loco and the Naked Chicken Chalupa – a taco encased in a shell of fried chicken.Chipotle has tried to position itself as a better, fresher alternative to typical fast-food brands. But it was rattled by a food-safety crisis in 2015, and attempts to whet customers’ appetites with new offerings like queso dip have largely fallen flat, leaving its share price wilted and leading Wall Street to question whether it can recapture its earlier mojo.Mr Ells said last year that he would cede the chief executive title once a replacement was found, although he will remain on as executive chairman. That led to speculation about who would get the nod, and how much free rein they would have to pursue their plans for spicing up Chipotle sales.Investors are clearly excited about seeing what Mr Niccol can do with Chipotle, and analysts were cautiously optimistic, while underscoring continued concerns about whether Chipotle’s sluggish sales growth is its new normal.“Mr. Niccol’s appointment will be viewed as a near-term catalyst for the stock given his experience repositioning the Taco Bell brand and successful execution across innovation, marketing, and value initiatives,” wrote Dennis Geiger of UBS. ““However, we continue to believe long-term headwinds remain, with a still challenged brand image and competitive pressures that will likely take time to address,” he added in a note on Wednesday. “Despite the announcement and our favorable view of Mr. Niccol’s appointment, we remain concerned Chipotle faces a new normal of lower sales & earnings growth going forward against a still elevated valuation”Chipotle shares fell 23.4 per cent in 2017 – their third year straight of double-digit percentage declines – and are nearly flat so far in 2018. Despite the jump, shares have only risen as high as $291.88 on Wednesday, a far cry from the peak of $758.61 seen in 2015. The stock dipped below $300 a share earlier this month following several analyst downgrades and lukewarm earnings.

Titular: Chipotle picks Taco Bell chief as new CEO
Texto: Chipotle shares are red-hot in after-hours trading after the fast-casual burrito chain named Brian Niccol, the chief executive of Mexican fast-food chain Taco Bell, to its top job.The long-awaited announcement sent Denver-based Chipotle shares up more than 10 per cent on Tuesday evening. Investors have been waiting to see who would replace Chipotle founder Steve Ells in the top job after he announced last year he would be stepping back — though still staying on as executive chairman.Mr Ells said in a statement:“Brian is a proven world-class executive, who will bring fresh energy and leadership to drive excellence across every aspect of our business. His expertise in digital technologies, restaurant operations and branding make him a perfect fit for Chipotle as we seek to enhance our customer experience, drive sales growth and make our brand more relevant.”Mr Niccol’s most recent job was chief executive of Taco Bell, a division of Yum Brands, a job he held since 2015. Before that, he held various other leadership positions at Taco Bell and fellow Yum Brands chain Pizza Hut, after getting his start at consumer giant Procter & Gamble.He said in a statement:“I am very excited to be joining Chipotle at this pivotal time in its history. I have tremendous respect for the Chipotle brand and its powerful purpose. At Chipotle’s core is delicious food, which I will look to pair up with consistently great customer experiences. I will also focus on dialling up Chipotle’s cultural relevance through innovation in menu and digital communications. This will attract customers, return the brand to growth, deliver value for shareholders and create opportunities for employees.”Yum Brands also announced on Tuesday that it had tapped Julie Fells Masino, president of Taco Bell North America, and Liz Williams, president of Taco Bell International, to lead that division after Mr Niccol’s departure.Chipotle has been looking to restore the sizzle the once-hot chain lost after a food-safety crisis in 2015, but has since been plagued with lacklustre growth. While Wall Street has been hoping that Mr Ells’ successor would help whet consumers’ appetites with fresh ideas, questions remain about whether the new chief will be allowed free rein, or whether Mr Ells’ continued presence will prove one too many cooks in the corporate kitchen.

Titular: Chipotle shares singed by growth worries, CEO search
Texto: Waiting for Chipotle’s fortunes to turn a corner? Get in line.As investors digested its latest batch of quarterly earnings, the fast-casual Mexican chain’s shares are down more than 10 per cent on Wednesday after worries about soggy traffic trends and its ongoing search for a new chief executive prompted Stifel analysts to downgrade the stock to a “sell”.On Tuesday, Denver-based Chipotle reported a doubling in quarterly profits to $43.8m from a year earlier, thanks to a boost from tax reform, and revenue of $1.1bn, in line with analysts’ forecasts. Comparable sales — a key industry metric — were up 0.9 per cent from a year ago, a hair above the 0.8 per cent analysts were looking for, with higher menu prices at certain restaurants helping to offset declining traffic.But for Chris O’Cull at Stifel, the uptick in same-store growth was nothing to cheer about, given the easy prior year comparsion when sales at the company were being rattled by a food-safety crisis.In a note Tuesday evening, Mr O’Cull wrote: “We expect negative traffic to persist. The company seems to be relying on easier comparisons this summer, rather than any initiatives to reverse the trend. We believe improving traffic could prove especially difficult following the 5% menu price increase.”Chipotle didn’t give Wall Street much to look forward to over for the coming year, either, with a forecast of comparable restaurant sales to increase in the low single digits, less than the 6.4 per cent growth registered in 2017.One thing that could kick Chipotle’s shares into high gear would be the expected naming of a new chief executive to replace Steve Ells, the company’s founder and chairman, who announced last year he would leave the top job whenever a successor was found.Mr Ells said on Tuesday that the company was “making good progress” on that search, and on the earnings call with investors, he said that the intention was “to have the new CEO be in charge.” But given that Mr Ells plans to shift into the job of executive chairman once his replacement takes over, it is still unclear how much influence he will retain over the company, or whether the new chief will have to struggle to put his or her vision into place.It “will be interesting to see if the EC reports to the CEO and also leads the board meetings,” Mr O’Cull wrote. “We struggle to see how any experienced CEO candidate would find this arrangement ideal for implementing change.”Stifel’s downgrade moves its rating on the stock from “hold” to “sell” and lowers its 12-month price target on shares from $310 to $250. Last week, UBS analysts also turned their noses up at Chipotle shares, downgrading it to a “sell” on similar concerns that it is “facing a new normal of lower growth.”Chipotle shares are down Wednesday 10.3 per cent to $272.91, putting them on track for their biggest one-day drop since October. Last year, Chipotle shares dropped 23.4 per cent and are down 5.7 per cent so far this year.

Titular: Stocks to watch: Investec, National Express, Capita, Snap
Subtitular: DRC tax row rattles Randgold, while Redburn eyes bus operators
Texto: The row over a draconian new mining code in the Democratic Republic of Congo is weighing on Randgold Resources. The refreshed code, which awaits signoff by DRC President Joseph Kabila, will hike extraction royalties and scrap standstill agreement clauses that protect mines from changes in the fiscal regime for 10 years.Randgold’s Kibali gold mine in DRC provides 20 per cent of 2017 group production and about 36 per cent of net present value, according to Barclays.With world market rebounding, Investec and Old Mutual are leading a rally for financial stocks. The pair were also helped by a strong South African rand, which was boosted by speculation that President Jacob Zuma’s resignation is imminent.GlaxoSmithKline advanced after its fourth-quarter revenue beat forecasts, thanks in part to robust sales of new products in its respiratory franchise.“The guidance for 2018 is encouraging and we believe is about 1 per cent ahead of consensus expectations adjusting for the multiple moving parts,” said Liberum. “This should settle nerves on the company’s expectations for HIV in a year when new competition is expected. We are also encouraged by the company being ‘increasingly confident’ in the longer term guidance to 2020 which consensus sits below.”Cardboard box maker Smurfit Kappa is under pressure even after delivering fourth-quarter results that matched market forecasts, as strength in Europe and cost savings offset tough trading in the Americas. A medium-term strategy update set out Smurfit’s plans to invest €1.6bn above maintenance capital expenditure by 2021 to take advantage of growth, integration and cost-savings opportunities.Goodbody Stockbrokers said: “We assume the share price reaction relates to the natural front-loading of cash expenditure before reaping the returns benefit. However, we would note that the investment plan is flexible in relation to market conditions and this management team has a strong track record of delivery.”Croda climbed after Reuters reported that the chemicals maker has ended talks to buy US-listed peer Ashland. Market speculation in recent days had linked Croda with a possible offer of around $93 a share for Ashland, which would have given the US group a market value of $5.7bn and would likely have required Croda to launch a rights issue.Redrow has jumped on better than expected interim results from the housebuilder, which came with a 50 per cent dividend hike. The group’s outlook statement also reassured, with reservations in the first five weeks of 2018 being in line with last year.Numis Securities upgraded Redrow to “buy”, saying: “The results highlight that Redrow’s past investment in land and WIP [work in progress] — rather than returning large amounts of capital to shareholders — is feeding through to strong levels of volume and profit growth. Sales so far in 2018 are in line with the strong comparative last year, and this, alongside the strong order book, give us confidence in the [outlook] for the full year.”In the US, Snap surged by as much as 35 per cent after reporting better than expected revenue and a surprise reacceleration of daily active user growth. It was the first beat since the Snapchat owner’s flotation last March.“We think the worst is behind Snap,” said Barclays. “We think shares could continue to grind higher as the narrative changes from 2017’s ‘Facebook is going to crush Snap’ to 2018’s ‘users and revenue accelerate and the platform is under-monetised’. Shares are expensive (8.3 times our 2019 revenue estimate), but everything is accelerating, and as we’ve seen repeatedly in consumer internet, these inflection points are not likely one-quarter events.”Chipotle Mexican Grill was a sharp faller after reporting a slow start to 2018. The restaurant chain said customer volumes had turned negative again, having failed to recover from last summer’s food safety scare.● Redburn starts coverage of the UK bus and rail operators, with the research house preferring buses over trains. FirstGroup and National Express are rated “buy”, with Stagecoach and Go-Ahead on “neutral” recommendations.“Somewhat surprisingly, we conclude opportunities abound. Our analysis of 147 regional bus subsidiaries confirms this is an idiosyncratic sector, but one in which growth and improving profitability can be driven through individual market characteristics, higher fuel prices and fleet investment. In less compelling regions, costs can be mitigated through network rationalisation.”“By contrast, the UK rail industry is structurally flawed. Heady passenger growth projections are needed to justify the premia, the major consideration in the Department for Transport bid process. However, with demand growth slowing, and operators locked into contracts with little protection, profitability will fall.”● Credit Suisse upgrades Rentokil Initial to “outperform” with a 330p target price. Its note highlights that the US makes up two-thirds of Rentokil’s pest control business, which accounts for 63 per cent of group revenues.“We think Rentokil can continue to take share in the US and, as it builds density . . . we think Rentokil’s position and brand in attractive end markets will support sustainable and consistent growth and value creation that we do not think is reflected in the current share price.”● HSBC cuts Capita to “hold” from “buy” with a target cut from 640p to 200p. It begins with a mea culpa:“We allowed enthusiasm for what we believe can be done with Capita by new management to overwhelm the scepticism with which we had viewed Capita for a number of years. There is, at this point, simply too much we do not know. [ . . .] We downgrade the stock to hold given the uncertainty around disposals, the unknown quantum of the discount on the rights issue and the upcoming strategy. Our turnround scenario suggests that the share price could more than double, over time, but it is too early to factor that into the valuation, as of yet, in our view.”● In brief: UBS upgrades Sage to “neutral”. Spectris upgraded to “overweight” at JPMorgan Cazenove. Royal Bank of Scotland raised to “hold” at Investec. Stifel raises Spirax Sarco to “buy”. Macquarie raises Diageo to “neutral”. Wärtsilä upgraded to “hold” from “reduce” at Kepler Cheuvreux.Global stocks find supportFor market updates and comment follow us on Twitter @FTMarkets

Titular: Higher prices, tax gain beef up Chipotle profit
Texto: Chipotle’s quarterly profit more than doubled from a year ago after the fast-casual burrito chain reaped the benefits of higher menu prices and recently enacted US tax reform.The company said on Tuesday that its revenue for the three months ending December 31 rose 7.3 per cent to $1.1bn, while comparable sales — a key industry metric — increased 0.9 per cent. The revenue figure came in line with analysts’ expectations, while comp sales managed to eke out a small beat over the 0.8 per cent that Wall Street was looking for.Chipotle attributed the comp sales gain to its decision to raise prices on some menu items at certain restaurants, which it said helped to boost average tickets to help balance out a decrease in transactions. The price hike also helped drive down food costs by 110 basis points versus the fourth quarter of 2016, to 34.2 per cent of revenue — as did its effort to save money on paper and packaging, along with cheaper avocados.Net income came in at $43.8m, compared to $16m during the same period a year earlier, with diluted earnings per share of $1.55, versus 55 cents a year ago. Earnings were lifted by a $6m, or 21 cent per share, tax benefit. Analysts had been looking for $37m in net income, or $1.32 a share.Steve Ells, Chipotle’s founder, chairman and chief executive, said in a statement:“During 2017, we have made considerable changes around leadership, operations, and long-term planning and it is clear that, while there is still work to be done, we are starting to see some success. 2018 marks the 25th anniversary of Chipotle, and I am encouraged by the dedication all of our guests and employees have to this brand. Our focus this year will be to continue perfecting the dining experience, enhancing the guest experience through innovations in digital and catering, and reinvesting in our restaurants. We are making good progress on our search for a new CEO who can improve execution, drive sales and enable Chipotle to realise our enormous potential.”Mr Ells announced last year that he will step down from the chief executive post once a replacement is found. The company has been grappling with how to spice up its sales and return to the red-hot growth that once made it a favourite of lunch-goers and investors before it was hit with a food-safety crisis starting in 2015.Its shares fell 23.4 per cent last year, and are up nearly 4 per cent year-to-date in 2018. They rose an additional 1.2 per cent in after-hours trading on Tuesday.

Titular: UBS downgrade dulls investor appetite for Chipotle
Texto: Can Chipotle get its sizzle back? Investors aren’t so sure, sending its shares down on Thursday after the US fast-casual burrito chain was downgraded to a “sell” by UBS.It’s been a bumpy ride for Chipotle over the past few years, after a red-hot growth streak came to an abrupt end when it was rattled by a food-safety scare, knocking its shares back from an all-time high of $758.61 in August 2015. After the food-safety revelations, shares have shed more than 20 per cent of their value in each of the past three years. The stock is currently trading at $309.63 after shedding another 4.7 per cent on Thursday.In November, its founder, Steve Ells, stepped down from the chief executive role, a spot the company has yet to fill. It has also rolled out new menu offerings, like queso dip, to try to juice up consumer enthusiasm.But online reviews have hit an all-time low, new offerings have done little to stave off fierce competition and unit-development expectations seem overly ambitious, according to UBS analyst Dennis Geiger, who said in a note Thursday that he believed Chipotle “is facing a new normal of lower growth.”Heightened competition, a difficult industry environment, and brand perception challenges highlight risks to sales & earnings growth. New product launches & increased marketing activity have not meaningfully accelerated growth, and we believe CMG is facing a new normal rather than an ongoing recovery.UBS lowered its 12-month rating on Chipotle from “neutral” to “sell” and dropped the price target from $345 to $290 a share.As part of its analysis, UBS said that it crunched more than 137,000 online customer reviews for Chipotle food – and discovered that diner satisfaction was coming apart faster than a soggy chip.The review “indicates a continued decline in scores since 2010 to historic lows,” the report said. “We remain concerned about deteriorating review trends & potential implications for the trajectory of sales.”Chipotle may be able to spice things up in the short term, with an expected boost from tax reform and infusion of new ideas when it finally names a new chief executive. But a longer-term shift in momentum seems less likely at the moment, Mr Geiger wrote:“We expect a new CEO announcement could be a catalyst for shares near-term. But long-term headwinds remain, with competition and a somewhat still challenged brand image as headwinds that could take time for an incoming CEO to effectively address. Opportunities likely exist across new product innovation, day parts (breakfast), remodels, technology, operations, and marketing, to name a few, but we don’t expect fixes to be quick.”Chart courtesy of UBS

Titular: Chipotle shares dip as officials investigate illness reports
Texto: Here we go again.Shares in Chipotle Mexican Grill took a knock on Wednesday after public health officials said they are investigating one of the burrito chain’s restaurants in Los Angeles following multiple reports of customers falling ill after eating there.The Los Angeles Health Department’s Acute Communicable Disease Control unit said in an email to the FT that it was “aware of reports of illness and is investigating.”Chipotle did not immediately respond to a request for comment.Shares in Chipotle fell nearly 3 per cent before trimming that loss to trade 2.5 per cent lower at $305.25.The news comes at a sensitive time for the fast-casual Mexican food chain, which has only started repairing its reputation and regaining diners following a series of food-safety incidents over the past two years.The health scares battered sales and wiped more than 60 per cent of the company’s market value from its peak in 2015. Last month, founder Steve Ells announced he was stepping down as chief executive, saying it “is the right thing to do for all our stakeholders.”“(W)hile we are continuing to make progress, it is clear that we need to move faster to make improvements,” he said in a statement at the time.

Titular: Chipotle: bacteria to basics
Subtitular: A founder becoming chairman risks too much interference in the business
Texto: Cheese with your Chipotle burrito? Please. Sour cream? Sure. Norovirus? Hold the norovirus. And maybe swap your inspirational founder for someone who knows more about running a substantial US fast-food chain.The Mexican restaurant chain is looking for a new chief executive after disasters that began with an E. coli outbreak in 2015 and continued this year with a data breach, storm damage and that norovirus attack. The shares have fallen three-fifths.On Wednesday, Chipotle said that founder Steve Ells would step down as CEO, restricting himself to the role of chairmanIf the word “executive” preceding that title acknowledges the thought leadership of Mr Ells in corn taco assembly, no problem. If the entrepreneur cannot resist overruling the newbie CEO, a 3 per cent jump in the shares will look overcooked.“An unco-operative Ells would be the biggest risk to a transition,” opines Bernstein’s Sara Senatore. A time comes in the life of most fast-growing businesses when the progenitor should cede control to a career manager. It is best to go quietly, as illustrated by the fraught removal of Travis Kalanick at online taxi group Uber.The need for change is glaring at Chipotle. Its problems with basic food hygiene bespeak sloppy processes and weak discipline. Recurrences could destroy this sometime Wall Street darling.They have already hurt comparable-store sales, which rose just 1 per cent in the third quarter. Operating margins have fallen to an unappetising 6 per cent, against 17 per cent historic and more than 30 per cent for McDonald’s.The shares are priced for a recovery and growth in the estate of 2,250 stores. At 33 times predicted 2017 earnings, they look pricey compared with rivals, if better value at 25 times for 2019.The stock should rise again if Chipotle hires a decent CEO. That should be easy enough. Harder to restrict Mr Ells to “innovation”. Too many cooks spoil the guacamole.The Lex team is interested in hearing more from readers. Is Chipotle poised for recovery? Or has it lost the plot for good? Please tell us what you think in the comments section below.

Titular: Chipotle founder to step down as CEO, become executive chairman
Texto: Chipotle founder Steve Ells is stepping down as chief executive of the fast-casual burrito chain in the wake of a series of food safety scandals and missteps that have wiped more than 60 per cent off the company’s market value since its peak in 2015.Chipotle said in a statement on Wednesday that the board has begun the search for a new CEO. Mr Ells will become executive chairman once a new CEO has been appointed.“Bringing in a new CEO is the right thing to do for all our stakeholders,” said Mr Ells. “….while we are continuing to make progress, it is clear that we need to move faster to make improvements.”Shares in the company – which were halted in pre-market trading ahead of the announcement – are down more than 40 per cent since May after it was hit by yet another food safety scandal. Its woes had been compounded by a data breach and a pair of hurricanes that pummeled southeastern US states this year which prompted a sharp drop in third quarter profit.In his new role as executive chairman, Mr Ells said he will be focused on “bringing innovation” to the way Chipotle food sourcing and preparation.Executive recruitment firm Spencer Stuart has been hired to assist in the search for a new CEO.(Photo: Getty)

Titular: McDonald’s flips fortunes with back-to-basics approach
Texto: It is the “dead zone” lull between lunch and dinner, yet McDonald’s is bustling with customers tapping their orders on huge screens. The Chicago store is acting as a blueprint for an overhaul of the world’s biggest fast-food chain in its biggest market. A glass case displays freshly baked apple pies and croissants. Smiling employees, dressed all in black, carry trays of burgers and fries to minimalist tables. “It doesn’t even smell like a McDonald’s,” says a colleague.When asked why he is spending $1.1bn to remodel thousands of US restaurants to mimic this one, Steve Easterbrook, McDonald’s chief executive, is interrupted by a customer who asks for his Instagram handle. “You have IG, right?”, he shouts, waving his iPhone. He is an aspiring photographer looking for social media followers, and his question answers mine — this is the consumer the 62-year-old burger chain is chasing.Mr Easterbrook, a soft-spoken British accountant, has worked at the fast-food chain for more than two decades. He took over in 2015 charged with reviving its reputation and regaining some of the half a billion customer orders it had lost in the US since 2012 and made it his mission to reinvent McDonald’s as a “modern, progressive burger company”.It is a phrase he used with investors when he first took the top job a month after the company reported its first annual drop in same-store sales in the US in 12 years. At the time observers declared the company, which helped define American diets, had lost its identity. Mr Easterbrook repeated the words throughout subsequent earnings calls.“That was sort of their North Star,” says Sara Senatore, an analyst at Bernstein. A former employee is more blunt, describing it as a “cliché phrase” that could mean “anything and everything”.However vague the plan remains, it does appear to be working. It is a challenging time for the US restaurant business. The industry has seen “little to no” growth in visits to restaurants in the past two years, according to market researchers NPD Group, while trade publication QSR declared last year the worst for restaurants since the financial crisis, after sales dropped sharply in the second half of the year. Grocery price deflation has made a stronger case for cooking at home, and a glut of restaurants has given people more choice if they do decide to go out.But after four years of shrinking traffic, McDonald’s this summer lured people back through its doors, posting a rise in customer visits in the second and third quarters. Comparable sales rose between 4 and 7 per cent each quarter this year. Investors have lauded Mr Easterbrook’s progress: the company’s share price has soared 70 per cent to $168 since he took over. The makeover has already been rolled out in much of Europe, with about one-third of French and German restaurants having been remodelled.McDonald’s feeds nearly 70m people every day, making the tale of how it dug itself out of “staggering” customer losses a case study for the business of eating. McDonald’s executives insist the success is built on a return to low prices and convenience, rather than chasing the whims of diners. With $25bn in annual sales and one of the most recognisable brands, the odds were in its favour to stage a comeback. But the way in which McDonald’s achieved it came as a surprise even to its own bosses.Back in 2014 the prevailing wisdom was that McDonald’s was being dethroned by new rivals such as Chipotle Mexican Grill, in a sector dubbed “fast casual”. These outlets emerged after the financial crisis with price points a few dollars higher than traditional fast food, but with a perception that the food might be healthier.Growth in global same-store sales for McDonald’s had been hovering around zero for the past few years, with demand sagging across the US, Asia and Europe, before plunging more than 3 per cent towards the end of 2014. This compelled Don Thompson, then chief executive, to promise “decisive action to fundamentally change” its business.He pledged to slash costs by $300m and open fewer stores, before being replaced by Mr Easterbrook four months later. Its market share of US fast food slipped from 17.4 per cent in 2012 to 15.4 per cent in 2016, according to Euromonitor.Last year Mr Easterbrook hired Lucy Brady, a longtime Boston Consulting Group executive, to investigate what was going wrong. She led a wide-ranging study to dissect where people were eating. Her results, which Mr Easterbrook describes as “frustrating, but actually reassuring”, showed that the majority of the missing McDonald’s customers were going to other burger chains, such as Wendy’s and Burger King rather than rival fast casual outlets.Customers didn’t stop wanting fast food, they just didn’t want McDonald’s fast food. Mr Easterbrook’s response was to adapt the “modern progressive” doctrine and adopt a less aspirational focus: “the day-to-day basics”. This has materialised in cutting prices for coffee and soda, serving breakfast all day, offering mobile ordering and delivery, and improving the quality, if not the nutritional value, of its food.“To Steve’s credit, he is not stubborn,” says Larry Light, McDonald’s former chief marketing officer. “Instead of trying to come up with new kale and bean salads, fix the familiar. Fast food is not in decline, and I think it will always be the number one way the world eats.”McDonald’s share of the US fast food market last year, down from 17.4% in 2012The market capitalisation of the fast-food chain. Its share price has risen 70% since 2015People eat at McDonald’s every day. The company has 37,000 restaurants worldwideTo walk through the McDonald’s campus is to go back in time. Four levels of faded brick balconies envelope a 1970s atrium, making it feel more like a bare bones public library than the headquarters of a $136bn burger company. The group is about to shift its offices to downtown Chicago, where its neighbours will include the likes of Google, after six decades sprawled across 150 wooded acres in suburban Illinois.Since first opening in 1955, McDonald’s has billed itself as a place to eat cheaply. It embedded fast food into American diets as the US industrial farm system developed to make $1 cheeseburgers feasible.McDonald’s executives, former employees and analysts all agree that pricing is one reason the company has bled customers.“McDonald’s lost the plot on value,” says Ms Senatore. “After the company stopped marketing its dollar value menu in 2013, they never came up with anything that was equally compelling.” The dollar menu accounted for about 14 per cent of total US sales at the time.After keeping a lid on prices for years, rising commodity costs and wages put pressure on the independent franchisees who operate most of its 37,000 worldwide restaurants. They began increasing prices, which “destroyed the overall value message”, says Richard Adams, former director of franchising for the western US, who has since sold his restaurants and now consults for other franchisees. “They couldn’t advertise the dollar menu [nationally] because franchisees had raised prices way above that.”Wendy’s and Burger King churned out deals such as four items for $4, helping each preserve a market share of about 11 per cent of the US fast food market, while growth in smaller chains such as Sonic Burger and Jack in the Box loosened McDonald’s grip on the market.Some question the wisdom of the company’s decision to begin customising its menu by region in 2004. Mr Light, who led the effort, says it was internally “controversial” for a company who had codified its menu down to how many pickles are placed on different burgers.By 2014, facing fast casual insurgents, McDonald’s took it one stage further, offering mixed and sometimes awkward messages about its menu. The company put clementines into Happy Meals and avocado on chicken sandwiches, while still trying to tap into burger nostalgia with adverts mocking the new lifestyle trends. “There will never be kale here,” declared a 2015 advert for the Big Mac.Under Mr Easterbrook’s watch, the company has taken a “barbell approach” to its menu, beefing up its offers on both the low and high end of prices. Discounts are a core part of the Easterbrook ethos, with McDonald’s churning out $1 and $2 offers for coffee and soda.In a nod to more health conscious consumers the chain has also promised to strip antibiotics from its chicken meat and corn syrup from bread buns, replaced butter with margarine and is working towards using fresh beef in its Quarter Pounders.But can the food be cheap and higher quality? “It’s about balance,” says Mr Easterbrook. “You can’t just go all in on the premium end, because then you disenfranchise more price-driven customers.” A new “value menu” will be unveiled next year, with price points of $1, $2 and $3.The premium offerings are not necessarily healthy. Its maple-bacon dijon sandwich with buttermilk crispy chicken contains 740 calories and 1,780mg of sodium, nearly 80 per cent of the recommended daily intakes. “American palates have become more sophisticated,” says Ms Senatore. “It’s not necessarily about lower calories, it’s about using whole foods, and McDonald’s is playing to that. But fundamentally the food is still pretty indulgent.”Mr Easterbrook spent much of his tenure in the UK defending the golden arches’ image, going so far as to request the Oxford English Dictionary change its definition of the phrase McJob from “an unstimulating, low-paid job”. The OED refused. But his tactics paid off, and he was credited with reviving British sales in 2006.For decades the company has taken flak for its implied role in the global obesity crisis. Governments are stepping up their healthy eating campaigns, which analysts warn could threaten McDonald’s recovery.They caution that the company is not out of the woods. “We may have seen the end of market share losses,” say analysts at RBC. “[But] in the past, headlines related to the obesity epidemic have resulted in negative publicity for McDonald’s.”Any new regulations, such as mandated calorie counts, could “negatively impact margins”, they added. Still, analysts who cover McDonald’s remain bullish: more than two-thirds rate it as a “strong buy” even after its stock has already soared by more than 40 per cent in the past year.The trend towards organic, customised products has jolted large consumer groups from PepsiCo to Procter & Gamble. While fielding online questions ranging from “do you even sell real food?” to “do you use pink slime in your burgers?”, McDonald’s now assures customers that it uses freshly cracked eggs in its Egg McMuffins and ground pork shoulder in its McRib sandwiches.“One of the most significant changes for all businesses since the financial crisis is consumers are more demanding and expect to know more about you,” Mr Easterbrook says. “They are more questioning of all authority . . . you are no longer in control of your message.”Bernstein’s Ms Senatore says it is “hard to argue that they haven’t improved the perception among at least some customers”.“Two years ago the question was whether [Mr Easterbrook] could bring what he did in the UK to the US, because it was such a bigger market,” she says. “It turned out that he could.”Ten years after the global financial crisis, America’s lopsided recovery can be seen in restaurants across the country. Unemployment has reached historic lows and wages are slowly rising, but consumers are still cautious with their money. The compound annual growth rate for the US restaurant industry was 6.4 per cent from 1970 to 2007, but that rate has slowed to about 4.3 per cent a year since the crisis.As the gap has widened between income groups, middle-of-the-pack restaurant chains such as Chili’s and Applebee’s are now struggling. With higher price points and largely outdated menus, analysts say these “casual dining” restaurants, where a customer can buy dinner at the mall for about $15, are more likely to have been the losers of the rise of Chipotle rather than McDonald’s.Meanwhile, “the price part of value remains the greater part of the overall restaurant selection decision, particularly with lower income consumers”, says Bill Fahy of Moody’s.This has supported fast-food sales, which have been resilient even as a cut-throat battle has broken out in the $800bn US restaurant industry. Executives say there are simply too many restaurants, and a lot of them are mediocre. There are now more than 600,000 places to eat and drink in the US, which has grown at nearly double the rate of the population, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.One of the biggest offenders in overbuilding has been the shiny new trend “fast casual”, as more and more companies have tried to replicate Chipotle’s success.However, it seems supply has outpaced demand, with the number of fast casual restaurants growing by 9 per cent last year, while sales in the segment slipped two per cent.

Titular: Storm-hit Chipotle set for worst slide in 5 years
Subtitular: US stocks retreat as Ackman loses $130m on burrito chain decline
Texto: Chipotle shares were on pace to suffer their greatest one-day loss in more than five years after the fast-casual burrito chain reported far weaker than expected profits in its third quarter.The company, which at one point was valued at more than $23bn, blamed a data breach it endured earlier this year as well as the effects of two hurricanes that pummeled the southern US earlier this year for its profit shortfall.Profits in the three months to the end of September rose 151 per cent to $19.6m, or 69 cents a share.That was less than half the level expected by analysts on Wall Street, who had projected earnings of $1.63 a share in the period.Shares in the group tumbled 14 per cent by midday on Wednesday to $277.56, pulling the company’s valuation below $8bn.The stock drop inflicted losses of about $130m on the hedge fund run by billionaire investor Bill Ackman, which disclosed a stake in the company last year.At the end of the second quarter, Pershing Square Capital Management reported holding 2.88m shares as part of regulatory filings.Chipotle’s decline led the S&P 500, which slipped 0.6 per cent on Wednesday to 2,553. The blue-chip Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.4 per cent to 23,348 and the technology-heavy Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.6 per cent to 6,557.Earnings that fell slightly below Wall Street expectations also weighed on MarketAxess, the largest corporate bond trading platform in the US.The company’s stock price fell 6.4 per cent to $178.03, it’s biggest one-day decline in two years.The stock drop accompanied news that rival Intercontinental Exchange had agreed to buy fixed-income trading platform BondPoint from Virtu Financial for $400m.Shares in ICE also dipped on Wednesday, falling 0.4 per cent to $65.01. Virtu shares rose 1.2 per cent to $14.68 but remain down 9.3 per cent in October ahead of the company announcing earnings in early November.MarketAxess had also looked at acquiring BondPoint, according to people familiar with the bidding process.“We are very interested in acquisitions that will add important clients to our system, new systems or new geographies — this deal didn’t do any of those,” said Rick McVey, chief executive of MarketAxess, speaking on the company’s earnings call on Wednesday morning in New York.It sets up the potential for ICE to go head to head with MarketAxess for a greater share of electronic corporate bond trading, said Patrick O’Shaughnessy, an analyst at Raymond James.But Mr McVey responded that the company had already weathered repeated challenges from both start-up venues and established players. “There is no sign of that changing,” he said.
