Titular: Hurricanes, data breach bite into Chipotle earnings
Texto: Chipotle shares crumbled in after-hours trading on Tuesday after the fast-casual burrito chain’s earnings badly missed expectations, a shortfall that the company blamed on fallout from a data breach and a pair of hurricanes that pummeled southeastern US states.The company — which has been trying to find its footing after a major food-safety crisis in 2015 — said that revenue for the three months ending September 30 was up 8.8 per cent from a year earlier to $1.13bn, in line with the expectations of analysts surveyed by Factset.However, profits were dented by charges related to a data breach announced earlier this year affecting some customers’ payment cards, as well as the impact from Hurricanes Irma and Harvey. Net income was $19.6m for the quarter, or 69 cents per diluted share, well below the $47m, or $1.67 per diluted share, that Wall Street was looking for.Comparable-store sales, a key industry metric, rose 1 per cent, just shy of the 1.1 per cent increase analysts were expecting.Steve Ells, the company’s chief executive and founder, said in a statement:We continued to make important progress to improve the guest experience at our restaurants during the quarter. Our strategic initiatives in operations, innovating our digital sales platform, new menu introductions, and marketing the brand are starting to take hold. Despite several unusual impacts during the quarter, including the impact of hurricanes, we maintained our focus and saw some encouraging signs. Our leadership remains focused on setting the foundation for future growth, and we are confident in our teams’ ability to deliver against those plans.Despite Mr Ells’ positive spin, Chipotle on Tuesday softened its comparable restaurant sales guidance for 2017. Previously looking for an increase in the high single digits, the company said that it is now expecting a more moderate 6.5 per cent increase.Chipotle has been pulling out the stops to try to lure back customers following the food-safety issues, including the introduction of cheesy queso dip, which has received mixed reviews from customers. The company’s shares, which are down 14 per cent year to date, dropped more than 8 per cent in after-hours trading following the announcement.

Titular: Panera spells out sugary drink details to customers
Subtitular: Sandwich chain uses cola cups listing teaspoons of sugar in move away from sodas
Texto: Panera is unveiling cups that list how many teaspoons of sugar have been added to drinks, as the sandwich company battles for the lunch money of more health-conscious American consumers.The new cups, which post sugar and calorie counts in large letters, reveal to customers that a 20oz serving of Pepsi, the cola Panera sells, has 17 teaspoons of sugar. This is more than double the sugar in Panera’s chocolate chip cookie, and also exceeds the daily limit of 12.5 teaspoons that the US government recommends.The move comes amid growing pressure from regulators and consumers for a reduction in sugar and salt, which are linked to obesity and diabetes.Panera has been a bright spot in an increasingly tough environment for eating out in the US. While traditional fast food stalwarts such as McDonald’s have grappled with a global shift in demand towards fresh food, Panera has benefited, with comparable sales growing between 4 and 5 per cent.This year JAB, the investment group backed by Germany’s billionaire Reimann family, bought Panera for $7.5bn, a marker of how investors value so-called “fast casual” restaurants. Panera’s move comes ahead of new government requirements for all packaged food and drinks to label added sugars, with a compliance date of 2018 recently pushed back. However, the sugar requirements did not apply to restaurants. “It’s up to companies to take the lead on transparency, not wait for legislation,” said Ron Shaich, Panera chief executive.It’s up to companies to take the lead on transparency, not wait for legislationAnother piece of Obamacare legislation requiring restaurant chains with at least 20 stores to post calorie counts on menus has also been delayed. Panera and some other restaurants already list nutrition information on food menus, but drinks increasingly have been a target in the battle against obesity. The company aims to shift more customers away from sodas, and the decision to post sugar in teaspoons instead of grams was deliberate, said Mr Shaich: “the only people who know what grams are are drug dealers”. Panera in March unveiled a new line of drinks with less or no sugar added, and says that since then 8 per cent of customers have opted for these drinks over soda.US soda sales have been falling for more than a decade as sweet drinks have come under fire from regulators and health officials for contributing to obesity. This week Coca-Cola, PepsiCo and other soft-drink makers agreed to limit the amount of sugar they use in beverages sold in Singapore. In the US, local governments in cities such as Seattle and Chicago have raised the idea of so-called soda taxes. Panera aims to roll out the cups across its 2,100 restaurants by next month. This year the Missouri-based company said it had stripped artificial ingredients from its food as part of a campaign to position itself as the healthier alternative to the likes of McDonald’s. McDonald’s has taken steps to stay relevant amid disruption by Panera and Chipotle. The world’s largest burger chain has removed artificial ingredients from chicken nuggets and said it would use fresh beef in quarter pounders. Shares in Panera have risen 46 per cent in the past year, while rival Chipotle’s stock has dropped 21 per cent.

Titular: Chipotle hit with subpoena over latest food-safety issue
Texto: US prosecutors have served Chipotle with a subpoena related to a food-safety issue at one of its restaurants this month as part of an ongoing probe into the US burrito chain.The group said in a regulatory filing on Wednesday that it received the subpoena on July 19, “requesting information related to illness incidents associated with a single Chipotle restaurant in Sterling, Virginia.”The US attorney’s office for central California, in conjunction with the US Food and Drug Administration’s office of criminal investigations, initially served Chipotle with a subpoena last January.Chipotle intends to “fully cooperate” with the probe, and added that it is “not possible at this time to determine whether we will incur … any fines or penalties in connection with the investigation pursuant to which the subpoena was issued.”Local health regulators said on Monday that 135 individuals reported falling ill after visiting the Virginia Chipotle restaurant between July 13 – 16.“Two ill patrons have tested positive for the same strain of norovirus. Based on symptoms reported and these preliminary laboratory results, the cause of the outbreak is believed to be norovirus, though the specific source of the norovirus has not yet been identified,” Loudoun County Health Department chief David Goodfriend said.John Hartung, Chipotle’s chief financial officer, said on a call with analysts on Tuesday evening that same-restaurant sales, an important industry metric, had been “negatively affected” by about 5.5 per cent on average over the last several days.He added that “it is too soon to know what enduring impact last week’s events may cause,” but that the group’s “hope is that the impact will fade over the coming weeks and that the marketing and buzz around the queso expanded test will change the narrative and encourage our guests to quickly return to their previous visit frequencies.”Norovirus is a highly-contagious illness that can cause an individual’s stomach or intestines to become inflamed, causing symptoms like stomach pain, nausea, diarrhea and vomiting, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.Chief executive Steve Ells apologised for the incident and said that it represented a “failure in one restaurant to comply with our procedures used to prevent norovirus.”The latest safety woes have reminded investors of a debacle in 2015 in which 485 people in 13 US states were sickened in outbreaks that were linked to Chipotle’s restaurants.Chipotle had been recovering, and in fact, its quarterly earnings that were disclosed on Tuesday exceeded analyst forecasts. The shares initially climbed, but then came under pressure by Wednesday morning, recently falling 1.3 per cent.

Titular: Chipotle maintains 2017 sales-growth forecast despite latest safety scare
Texto: Burrito chain Chipotle is sticking with its previous forecast for comparable restaurant sales growth in the high single digits this year, even as it hopes to move quickly past the latest food-safety concerns linked to one of its restaurants.The company’s shares rose 2.5 per cent in after-hours trading after it reported better-than-expected profits during the three months ending June 30. Net income for the quarter was $66.7m, 161 per cent higher than the $25.6m income during the same period a year earlier, and better than the $62.3m that analysts surveyed by Bloomberg had expected.Diluted earnings per share also outstripped the year-ago period, coming in at $2.32, versus analysts’ expectations for $2.17. Revenue grew 17.1 per cent year-on-year to $1.17bn, a hair shy of the $1.18bn that Wall Street was looking for.Food costs ate up a slightly smaller share of its sales than the same period last year, the company said, with higher avocado costs offset by reduced costs from bringing preparation of lettuce and bell peppers back in-house, as well as higher menu prices that debuted in certain restaurants during the past quarter.Comparable restaurant sales, however, fell short of forecasts, clocking in at an 8.1 per cent gain, compared to expectations for a 9.5 per cent boost.Chipotle was once a rising star in the fast-casual dining sector until it took a hit from a food-safety crisis in 2015, when a series of multiple foodborne-illness outbreaks sickened dozens of people in 13 US states, spooking investors.Just as Chipotle seemed to be putting that behind it, another food-safety issue cropped up earlier this month when it temporarily shut down a restaurant in Virginia after reports that customers fell ill after eating there.Last month, Chipotle shares were also rattled by a warning it issued on marketing expenses, which raised concerns that its profit margins were under pressure. Nevertheless, in its report on Tuesday, Chipotle said that marketing and promotional expenses accounted for 3.7 per cent of sales, 70 basis points lower than the same quarter last year.Chipotle chief executive Steve Ells said in the release:We saw encouraging signs in our improved financial results during the first half of the year. Recent events, however, have shown that we still have a lot of opportunity to improve our operations and deliver the outstanding experience that our customers expect.The company, whose shares have fallen 22.5 per cent over the past 12 months, said it is still looking for comparable restaurant sales growth in the high single digits and plans to open between 195 and 210 new restaurants.

Titular: Harley shares skid on disappointing earnings
Subtitular: Bank stocks struggle after Goldman and BofA deliver poorly-received results
Texto: Harley-Davidson was the worst performer on the S&P 500 on Tuesday after the motorcycle maker posted a downbeat outlook and poor US sales in the second quarter, sending its shares down by their biggest one-day drop in a year.The Milwaukee-based company now expects to ship 241,000 to 246,000 motorcycles to dealers worldwide this year, down 6 to 8 per cent from a year ago. In the current quarter, it also expects shipments to be down 10 to 20 per cent from a year ago.Shares in the company fell 5.9 per cent to $48.95 by the close of trading.Second-quarter revenue decreased 5.6 per cent to $1.58bn, compared with Wall Street estimates of $1.6bn. Investors were also disappointed after Harley said US retail motorcycle sales were down 9.3 per cent from a year ago.“We believe soft, used motorcycle prices adversely affected the industry new motorcycle sales in the quarter,” said chief financial officer John Olin on an earnings call. The used motorcycle market could pose a challenge for the company to meet its goal of adding 2m riders in the US by 2027.However, while, profits slid to $258.9m, or $1.48 a share, compared with $280.4m, or $1.55 a share, in the year ago period, they topped analysts’ expectations of $1.39 a share.The slump in Harley shares came alongside mixed trading for Wall Street. The S&P 500 gained less than 0.1 per cent to 2,460.61, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average was off 0.3 per cent to 21,574.73 and the Nasdaq Composite was 0.5 per cent higher at 6,344.31.Financials were among the worst performing sectors, off 0.3 per cent following poorly received results from Goldman Sachs and Bank of America. A Republican move to abandon their efforts to replace Obamacare also renewed investor concerns about President Donald Trump’s ability to deliver on his economic agenda.Elsewhere, investors also soured on Chipotle after the burrito chain said it temporarily closed one of its restaurants following reports that customers fell ill after eating there, reigniting memories of a painful food-safety scare in 2015.Jim Marsden, the group’s food safety chief, said that Chipotle was working with local health authorities to “understand what the cause may be and to resolve the situation as quickly as possible”.He added that the symptoms were consistent with a highly contagious illness called norovirus. The infection is generally spread through food, water or touching contaminated surfaces, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. It causes unpleasant gastrointestinal symptoms, ranging from stomach pain to diarrhoea and vomiting.“Norovirus does not come from our food supply, and it is safe to eat at Chipotle. We plan to reopen the restaurant today,” Mr Marsden said.For investors, the incident hearkens back to the crisis the company faced in 2015 when a series of at least six outbreaks were thought to have caused sickness in 485 people across 13 US states.Chipotle shares dropped 4.3 per cent to $374.98 on Tuesday. They have yet to recover even close to the record closing high of $757.77 they struck in August 2015.

Titular: Chipotle hit after reports customers fell ill after eating at Virginia restaurant
Texto: Chipotle shares fell on Tuesday after the burrito chain said it temporarily closed one of its restaurants following reports that customers fell ill after eating there, reigniting memories of a painful food-safety scare in 2015.Jim Marsden, the group’s food safety chief, said that Chipotle is working with local health authorities to “understand what the cause may be and to resolve the situation as quickly as possible.”He added that the symptoms are consistent with a highly contagious illness called norovirus. We plan to reopen the restaurant today,” Mr Marsden said.David Goodfriend, director of the Loudoun County Health Department that is conducting an initial investigation, said that officials had not yet determined that norovirus was the cause of the reported illnesses, saying that “at this point we are investigating all possibilities.”“We will be submitting specimens for testing if it appears that would be beneficial after our initial investigation this afternoon,” he added.For investors, the incident hearkens back to the crisis the company faced in 2015 when a series of at least six outbreaks were thought to have caused sickness in 485 people across 13 US states.Chipotle shares dropped almost 6 per cent to $368.15. They have yet to recover even close to the record closing high of $757.77 they struck in August 2015.

Titular: Chipotle slides after warning on expenses rattles burrito chain
Subtitular: S&P 500 and Dow give up ground after reaching record highs on Monday
Texto: Chipotle recorded its worst one-day fall this year, after a warning over marketing expenses sparked concern among investors that the burrito chain’s profit margins are under pressure.The Denver-based group said that it expected marketing and promotional costs to rise by 0.2 to 0.3 percentage points in the current quarter from the first three months of this year, to 3.6-3.7 per cent of sales.The stock slumped 7.3 per cent on Tuesday to $425.60 a share, its heaviest one-day fall since December 6 2016.Chipotle forecasts that “other” operating costs as a proportion of sales to be “at or slightly higher than reported for the first quarter”. Other operating expenses, which include marketing costs along with a handful of other items, represented 4.1 per cent of revenues in the first quarter, according to regulatory filings.Other expenses jumped to 16.4 per cent of sales in 2016, from just 11.4 per cent the year prior as Chipotle launched an aggressive advertising campaign aimed at bringing customers back though its doors after its food-safety crisis in late 2015.Mark Kalinowsk of Nomura noted that he believes “continued investments will be required” to rev up sales growth this year and next. He cut his outlook for earnings per share for 2017 and 2018 and reduced his price target on the stock almost 6 per cent to $480 a share.Chipotle, once a Wall Street high flyer, came under intense pressure in late 2015 after a series of at least six food-safety outbreaks linked to the chain caused sickness in 485 people in 13 US states. The crisis weighed heavily on Chipotle’s sales and sent the stock plummeting from an all-time closing high in August 2015 of $757.77.Steve Ells, chief executive, has emphasised the group’s focus on better-quality ingredients as part of his bid to boost the customer experience and reinvigorate sales. As part of that push, Chipotle said in March that it rid the chain of any artificial colours, flavours and preservatives, something it claims no other US fast-food chain has accomplished.He has also launched programmes aimed at reducing employee turnover and boosting the levels of customer service provided by its workers.“I’m as optimistic as I’ve ever been since starting Chipotle nearly 24 years ago. Since last fall, when I acknowledged that many of our restaurants were not meeting my expectations, we have made incredible progress,” Mr Ells said in April of this year.Looking more broadly, after setting new intraday and closing highs on Monday the markets retreated, with the S&P 500 ending the day 0.7 per cent lower at 2,437. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, which also notched new lifetime highs slipped 0.3 per cent to 21,467, while the Nasdaq Composite shed 0.8 per cent to 6,188.

Titular: Chipotle slides 6% after warning of higher marketing expenses
Texto: Chipotle was on track to post its worst fall this year, after the US burrito chain warned that its marketing expenses have eaten up a greater share of sales in the current quarter than at the start of 2017 as it works to lure customers back after its food-safety crisis in late 2015.The Denver-based group said that it expects marketing and promotional costs to be up 0.2 – 0.3 percentage points in the current quarter from the first three months of this year, to 3.6 – 3.7 per cent of sales.As a result, Chipotle expects its “other” operating costs as a proportion of sales to be “at or slightly higher than reported for the first quarter”. Other operating expenses, which include marketing costs along with a handful of other items, clocked in at 14.1 per cent of revenues in the first quarter, according to regulatory filings.Other expenses jumped to 16.4 per cent of sales in 2016, from just 11.4 per cent the year prior as Chipotle launched an aggressive advertising campaign aimed at bringing customers back though its doors.Chipotle’s warning late on Monday that it expects higher promotional expenses in the second quarter of this year sparked concern over profit margins.Mark Kalinowsk of Nomura noted that he reckons “continued investments will be required” to rev up sales growth this year and next. He cut his outlook for earnings per share for 2017 and 2018 and reduced his price target on the stock almost 6 per cent to $480 a share.The shares were down 6.2 per cent on Tuesday to $430.27, leaving Chipotle poised for its heaviest fall since December 6, 2016.Chipotle, once a Wall Street high flier, came under intense pressure in late 2015 after a series of at least six food-safety outbreaks linked to the chain caused sickness in 485 people in 13 US states. The crisis weighed heavily on Chipotle’s sales and sent the stock plummeting from an all-time closing high in August 2015 of $757.77.Chief executive Steve Ells has emphasised the group’s focus on better-quality ingredients as part of his bid to rev up the customer experience and reinvigorate sales. As part of that push, Chipotle said in March that it rid the chain of any artificial colours, flavours and preservatives, something it claims no other US fast-food chain has accomplished.He has also launched programmes aimed at reducing employee turnover and boosting the levels of customer service provided by its workers.“I’m as optimistic as I’ve ever been since starting Chipotle nearly 24 years ago. Since last fall, when I acknowledged that many of our restaurants were not meeting my expectations, we have made incredible progress,” he said in April of this year.

Titular: Emerging market debt burdens may be sorely understated
Subtitular: Recent paper suggests overseas liabilities of EMs are greater than previously thought
Texto: For emerging economies, coronavirus struck first through the financial markets. Long before the numbers of cases and deaths in these countries began to spread alarm, many emerging markets experienced a sudden halt in foreign investment inflows.Overseas investors have taken $95bn out of EM stocks and bonds since late January, according to the Institute of International Finance, dwarfing the withdrawals that followed the onset of the global financial crisis in September 2008.As Covid-19 infections rise and fragile health systems struggle to cope, foreign investors may be low on the list of concerns for EM governments. But these outflows will have a big impact on the fiscal measures policymakers can bring to bear on the crisis.Emerging markets’ overseas liabilities, moreover, may be bigger than previously imagined. A paper published by Matteo Maggiori at Stanford and colleagues at Harvard, Chicago Booth and Columbia Business School suggests the true ownership of EM bonds by overseas investors is much greater than shown in standard data — in some countries, by many multiples.The paper also suggests that foreign holdings of shares issued by Chinese companies may be many times greater than the $160bn that shows up in US national accounts. Should US-China relations sour in the aftermath of the coronavirus crisis, these giant holdings could become a source of significant risk.Mr Maggiori and his colleagues question the normal practice of allocating securities in national accounts on the basis of the residency rather than the nationality of their issuer. It may make sense, for example, for a bond issued by a Brazilian subsidiary of Banco Santander to be added to the debt statistics of Brazil (the residency of its issuer) rather than Spain (the nationality of the issuer’s ultimate owner), because the bond’s proceeds are likely to be put to use in Brazil.But it makes much less sense for a bond issued by Petrobras International Finance Company, a Cayman Island subsidiary of the Brazilian oil group, to be added to the debt statistics of the Cayman Islands. Yet that is what happens in standard, residency-based financial statistics such as the US’s Treasury International Capital data (TIC) and the IMF’s Coordinated Portfolio Investment Survey (CPIS).Mr Maggiori says this results in a vast understatement of the investments by US, European and other international investors in emerging economies. So the academics developed an algorithm to reallocate the securities logged in the TIC and CPIS data according to nationality rather than residency.The results are startling. TIC data show that US ownership of Brazilian bonds at the end of 2017 amounted to $8bn, based on the residency of issuers. But restated by nationality, the total rises to $68bn. For Chinese bonds, the total rises from $3bn to $55bn. Mr Maggiori says the results sound a warning as the coronavirus crisis threatens to tip emerging markets into a debt crisis.“If we are going to see a wave of corporate defaults, it’s a risk worth thinking about that a lot of issuance has taken place offshore,” he said. “[Our work] shows that exposures are quite large.”What is also striking is the role played by tax havens such as the Cayman Islands. In the TIC data, of Brazil’s $59bn in reallocated bonds, $42bn were issued in tax havens. Of China’s $52bn, $44bn were issued in tax havens. The results also shine a light on the role of so-called variable interest equity structures in US investments in Chinese companies. VIEs allow US investors to hold shares in these companies, circumventing Chinese restrictions on foreign ownership of some operating businesses. But in these transactions what investors actually buy are shares in listed companies, generally resident in the Cayman Islands, that give them a claim on the profits of Chinese operating businesses.By reallocating such investments on the basis of nationality rather than residence, the paper shows that US “ownership” of Chinese companies at the end of 2017 was not $160bn, as shown in US national statistics, but $700bn. This puts it closer to the amount of Chinese ownership of US Treasuries, of about $1.1tn. This is significant because Chinese regulators are certainly aware of the smoke-and-mirrors act being carried out by VIEs. They could, should they wish, bring the practice to an end.Mr Maggiori is not suggesting they will. But he thinks the risk is worth noting. “You read a lot about the possibility of China dumping its US Treasuries but very little about the possibility of China imposing its own regulations. If we’re talking about one, we should certainly be talking about the other,” he said.jonathan.wheatley@ft.com

Titular: Chipotle shares rise as comparable sales rebound sharply
Texto: Chipotle’s comeback from a bruising food-safety crisis seems to be picking up steam, sending shares in the Mexican fast-casual eatery chain higher in after-hours trading on Tuesday.The company said that revenue for the quarter came in at $1.08bn, a 28.1 per cent increase from its dismal first quarter last year — when it was still suffering the ill effects of its food-safety issues — and ahead of analysts’ expectations for $1.05bn in sales.Comparable sales — a key industry metric — were up 17.8 per cent, better than the robust 15.4 per cent that Wall street had been looking for.Net income for the quarter ending March 31 was $46.1m, compared to a net loss of $26.4m during the year-ago quarter, translating to earnings per diluted share of $1.60 versus a net loss of 88 cents last year. That compared to Wall Street’s expectations for $37.8m profit and earnings per share of $1.29.The strong earnings initially sent Chipotle shares up 6.6 per cent in after-hours trading.However, the company said in its analyst conference call that it had hired a cyber security group to investigate “unauthorized activity on a network that supports payment processing” that it believes has since stopped. Shares gave up most of their gains as investors parsed the news.Steve Ells, the company’s founder, chairman and chief executive said:“2017 is off to a strong start, as our restaurant managers and teams are energized by our renewed focus on the customer. By simplifying the focus in our restaurants to only those elements that lead to a great guest experience, our operations have improved every single month, which gives us confidence that we are on our way to achieve our mission to ensure that great food made with whole unprocessed ingredients is accessible to everyone.”

Titular: Chipotle removes last preservatives from ingredient list
Texto: Chipotle has banished preservatives from its tortillas as the US burrito chain that is in the midst of a rebound from a food-safety scare looks to bolster its appeal among ingredient-conscious diners.The Denver-based chain said it is now the only national restaurant brand with no added colours, flavours or preservatives in any of its ingredients, heightening the claims of its already popular ad campaign that emphasises quality ingredients.The Mexican-food inspired chain has been recovering from a 2015 food-safety debacle that sparked a deep decline in sales and sent its shares tumbling from all-time highs.The roll out of better ingredients through its “food with integrity” mission should enhance the appeal of Chipotle’s brand over time, according to analysts at Baird Equity Research. “Using such products results in better-tasting food and leverages a concept that is highly popular with consumers,” wrote David Tarantino, a senior research analyst.To drive sales in 2017 and beyond, Mr Tarantino said marketing and menu innovations would play a key role, especially in the group’s aim to win back customers.Chipotle disclosed a 4.8 per cent fall in same-store sales in the fourth quarter, representing a recovery from the 21.9 per cent drop in the previous three-month period. The group said in February that it expects the key sales metric to increase in the “high-single digits” this year.Shares in Chipotle, which are down 9.9 per cent over the past 12 months, gained 3.1 per cent on Tuesday to $427.74. They peaked at $758.61 in August 2015.

Titular: Chipotle shares dip as revenue falls just short of estimates
Texto: Chipotle shares dipped 2.5 per cent in after-hours trading on Thursday after it unveiled slightly softer-than-expected revenue from the past quarter, even as it reaffirmed its commitment to growing same-store sales in the new year.The company – which has been clawing its way back after a food-safety scare – said that revenue for the three-month period ending December 31 was $1bn, a hair shy of the $1.03bn that analysts had predicted, according to Bloomberg. Earnings per share were 55 cents, a penny short of the 56 cents a share targeted by Wall Street.The company attributed the modest revenue growth to the 72 new restaurants it had opened during the quarter. As it had previously announced, same-store sales for the full quarter had declined 4.8 per cent – although they had improved during that time from a 20.2 per cent decrease in October to a positive 14.7 per cent in December.Profits, however, slightly edged out expectations of $15.75m, coming in at $16m for the quarter but a steep decline from the year-ago period, when it clocked income of $67.9m. The company said that its food costs had crept up 150 basis points compared with the same quarter in 2015, with pricier avocados and more costly diced tomatoes partly offset by cheaper beef.Chipotle reaffirmed its outlook of single-digit comparable-store sales growth in 2017. Chief executive and founder Steve Ells said:“In the upcoming year we intend to continue to simplify and improve our restaurant operations, utilize creative marketing to rebuild our brand, and further the roll-out of our digital sales efforts. All three of these strategic initiatives are centered on improving the guest experience and restoring customer affinity for the Chipotle brand, and we are confident in our teams’ abilities as we start this new year.”

Titular: Chipotle shows signs of emerging from food safety crisis
Subtitular: Burrito chain’s shares rally as sales return to growth in December
Texto: Chipotle extended its 2017 share price rally on Tuesday as glimmers of hope emerged that the US burrito chain may finally be placing its food safety crisis behind it.The Colorado-based company said like-for-like sales swung from a drop of 20.2 per cent in October, to a fall of 1.4 per cent in November and growth of 14.7 per cent in December.While Chipotle cautioned that the rise was attributable to an easier comparison in the year-prior period, it marks one of the first indications that it may have stemmed the decline that has sent its shares plummeting by almost 45 per cent from a record high recorded in August 2015.Chipotle, once a Wall Street high flyer, was pounded in 2016 as sales fell when it struggled to recover from the aftershocks of a tainted food debacle in the previous year that caused sickness in 485 people in 13 US states.The reverberations are still hitting Chipotle’s profits, however. The restaurant that is known for its Mexican-inspired dishes said on Tuesday that fourth-quarter earnings are expected to be in the range of 50-58 cents a share, nearly half Wall Street expectations of 96 cents.Chipotle said it spent more than it expected on promotions and on testing television advertisements. An increase in the price of avocados also took a toll.The shares rose 5.7 per cent on Tuesday to $417.52, and have risen more than a tenth since the end of 2016.

Titular: Chipotle warns Q4 results to miss Wall St estimates
Texto: Chipotle on Tuesday disclosed preliminary figures indicating that its fourth-quarter results will miss Wall Street expectations as the US burrito chain faced higher-than-expected promotional expenses and was stung by rising avocado prices.The Colorado-based company said that its like-for-like sales declined by 4.8 per cent in the final quarter of 2016. Analysts were expecting a fall of 3.7 per cent, according to Bloomberg data.Shares skidded by 3.9 per cent in pre-market trading, which would cut its gains since the end of 2016.The decline in sales comes as the company that is famous for its guacamole and other Mexican-inspired dishes attempts to turn itself around from a food-safety crisis last year.Chipotle said its expects to post fourth quarter sales of $1.035bn, shy of forecasts calling for $1.049bn. Meanwhile, profits are expected to be in the range of 50 – 58 cents a share, also missing the consensus call for 96 cents.The chain said that it spent more than it had originally expected on promotions and on testing television advertisements. An increase in the price of avocados also hit its bottom line.On an upbeat note, Chipotle’s like-for-like sales swung from a fall of 20.2 per cent in October, to a decline of 1.4 per cent in November and a rise of 14.7 per cent in December. The company pegged the shift on easier comparisons to lower sales levels in the year-prior period.

Titular: Chipotle bows to pressure from Bill Ackman with board shake-up
Subtitular: US burrito chain names four new directors as it looks to stem sales decline
Texto: Chipotle, the US burrito chain whose sales have tumbled since a food safety scare last year, has shaken up its board of directors as part of an agreement with activist investor Bill Ackman.Denver-based Chipotle on Friday named four new directors to its board, two of whom are longtime allies of Mr Ackman.The pact comes as Chipotle has struggled to stem a sharp decline in sales that was prompted by a number of incidents of food contamination last year that caused sickness in 485 people across 13 US states.Steve Ells, Chipotle chief executive, said the changes strengthened “our board of directors, and gives us the oversight, accountability and leadership we need as we continue our efforts to re-establish Chipotle as the leader we have been for much of our history”.This week, Mr Ells, who founded the group in 1993 and is also the board chairman, was named as sole chief executive after co-CEO Monty Moran stepped down.Pershing Square, the activist hedge fund run by Mr Ackman, disclosed in September that it had a nearly 10 per cent stake in the company, making it Chipotle’s biggest shareholder.As part of the deal, Pershing, known for its heated rhetoric about the companies in which it is trying to agitate change, agreed to not make disparaging remarks for at least two years, according to a filing with US securities regulators. Pershing also will not raise its stake in Chipotle to more than 12.9 per cent without approval from the company’s board.“We are pleased that Chipotle has taken the important step of refreshing its board which will position the company for continued growth and long-term success,” said Mr Ackman. “We look forward to working with the board and management to create sustained value for all shareholders for many years to come.”Among the new directors is Ali Namvar, a Pershing partner who has been with the group since 2006 and Matthew Paull, a former McDonald’s chief financial officer who is on Pershing’s advisory panel and the board of Air Products, one of the fund’s portfolio companies.Paul Cappuccio, chief legal officer at Time Warner and Liberty Global executive Robin Hickenlooper have also been appointed.Shares in Chipotle, once a Wall Street high flyer, have dived from their record high of $757.77 last August as investors have grown impatient with the company’s sales performance. Shares rose 2.7 per cent to $392.55 on Friday morning.Same-store sales for the three months to the end of September slumped 21.9 per cent, the fourth-straight double-digit revenue fall for a company that had previously never reported a drop in the metric since its 2006 initial public offering.The rate of decline has slowed since peaking at nearly 30 per cent in the first three months of 2016. However, Mr Ells spooked investors this month by warning that he was still “not satisfied with the rate of recovery” and that sales have remained “uneven” and “difficult to predict”.Additional reporting by Stephen Foley

Titular: Chipotle shakes up board in deal with Bill Ackman
Texto: Chipotle, the US burrito chain that has seen its shares collapse since a food-safety scare last year, has shaken-up its board of directors in a deal with activist investor Bill Ackman.Denver-based Chipotle said it has named four new directors to its board, who will serve an initial term through the company’s annual shareholder meeting next year. The pact comes as Chipotle has struggled to stem a sharp decline in sales that has come after a string of food-safety issues last year sickened 485 people in 13 US states.“The addition of these new directors strengthens our Board of Directors, and gives us the oversight, accountability and leadership we need as we continue our efforts to reestablish Chipotle as the leader we have been for much of our history,” said Steve Ells, chief executive.Pershing Square disclosed in September a nearly 10 per cent stake in the company. The activist hedge fund run by Mr Ackman is Chipotle’s biggest shareholder, according to data from Bloomberg.“We are pleased that Chipotle has taken the important step of refreshing its Board which will position the company for continued growth and long-term success. We look forward to working with the Board and management to create sustained value for all shareholders for many years to come,” said Mr Ackman.

Titular: Chipotle shares jump on streamlined leadership plan
Subtitular: Defence contractors hit as Lockheed Martin knocked by Trump’s tweet
Texto: Investors sank their teeth into Chipotle on Monday, sending shares up more than 3 per cent after the fast-casual burrito chain announced a streamlined corporate leadership structure.Chipotle said it planned to return to having one chief executive following the departure of co-chief executive Monty Moran, with immediate effect. Mr Moran is also stepping down from his board seat and is retiring next year.Steve Ells, founder and chief executive, will continue on as the sole chief executive as well as chairman.Chipotle is attempting to bounce back from a food safety crisis last year linked to its restaurants that sickened dozens in multiple states.Chipotle’s operations have in recent years become “overcomplicated”, Mr Ells said in a statement on Monday. He also announced that he would be looking into employee incentives more closely linked to improving customer experience, an area in which he recently said he believed the restaurant chain was lagging behind.From a year ago, Chipotle’s shares have fallen more than 32 per cent, closing on Monday at $382.48. Its woes have attracted the attention of Pershing Square Capital Management, the hedge fund run by billionaire Bill Ackman, which disclosed it had taken a 9.9 per cent stake in the company.In another executive shake-up, shares in Alexion Pharmaceuticals dropped 12.9 per cent to $115.08 after the Connecticut-based biotechnology group said its chief executive and chief financial officer had resigned.Chief executive David Hallal, who has been in that role since 2015, was leaving with immediate effect, the company said. David Brennan, previously chief executive of British drugmaker AstraZeneca and a member of Alexion’s board, will take over as interim chief. Meanwhile, chief financial officer Vikas Sinha will be replaced by David Anderson, the former CFO of Honeywell.The departures come a month after Alexion said it would delay its quarterly filing in order to investigate allegations of improper sales practices related to its top-selling drug Soliris, which treats a rare blood disease. That investigation is “nearing completion”, the company said on Monday, and has not yet identified any facts that require updating its previously reported results.US aerospace group Lockheed Martin found itself on the receiving end of a tweet from US president-elect Donald Trump on Monday morning, who said that its F-35 fighter jet programme and cost “is out of control”. The message sent Lockheed’s shares down 5.2 per cent to $245.95, and rattled stocks of some other big defence contractors. Its shares later recovered some ground and closed down 2.5 per cent at $253.11. BAE Systems shares slipped 0.1 per cent to $30.36, Northrop Grumman declined 2.7 per cent to $232.07 and Raytheon fell 1.7 per cent to $143.81.The big US stock indices were relatively calm on Monday after trading in record territory after the open. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained another 0.2 per cent to 19,796, buoyed by energy stocks surging on the back of rising oil prices. The S&P 500 was off 0.1 per cent at 2,256, while the Nasdaq dropped 0.6 per cent to 5,412.

Titular: Chipotle shares perk up as co-CEO departs
Texto: Investors sank their teeth into Chipotle on Monday, sending shares of the fast-casual burrito chain up more than 3 per cent after it announced it will return to having just one chief executive following the departure of co-chief executive Monty Moran.Mr Moran, whose previous roles at Chipotle have included chief operating officer and general counsel, was elevated to co-chief executive in 2009 alongside Chipotle’s founder Steve Ells. He will leave his co-chief executive seat immediately, along with his seat on the company’s board, and retire from the company next year, Chipotle said in a statement.Mr Ells, a classically trained chef who founded Chipotle 23 years ago, will continue on as the sole chief executive as well as the company’s chairman, in a move designed to streamline its corporate leadership as it attempts to bounce back from a food-safety crisis last year linked to its restaurants that sickened dozens in multiple states.Chipotle’s operations have in recent years become “over-complicated,” Mr Ells said in a statement on Monday. “I’m very much looking forward to relentlessly focusing on ensuring an excellent guest experience, removing unnecessary complexity from our operations, championing innovation and pursuing our mission of making better food accessible to more people.”Mr Ells also announced that he would be looking into employee incentives more closely linked to improving customer experience, an area in which he recently said the restaurant chain was lagging. Failure to deliver a solid guest experience would harm Chipotle’s efforts to lure customers back to the store, and “needlessly slow” its recovery from the recent foodborne-illness outbreaks linked to its stores, Mr Ells told investors earlier this month at a conference in New York.Compared to a year ago, Chipotle’s shares have fallen more than 31 per cent as it attempts to make up lost ground. The company’s third-quarter results showed same-store sales had declined 21.9 per cent on a year-on-year basis during that three-month period, and it said it hopes to pare its losses in coming months and return to single-digit growth by next year.Chipotle’s woes have attracted the attention of Pershing Square Capital Management, the hedge fund run by billionaire Bill Ackman, which disclosed it had taken a 9.9 per cent stake in the company. The fund is expected to push for corporate governance changes and operational improvements.

Titular: Chipotle shares slide on slow health scare recovery
Subtitular: US stocks edge higher as Nike also weighs on indices
Texto: Chipotle shares slid on Tuesday after its chief executive said he was “not satisfied with the rate of recovery” from a food safety scare at the fast-casual burrito chain.During an investor conference on Tuesday, Chipotle chief Steve Ells called 2016 the most challenging year for the company.While sales have started to creep back, they remain “uneven” and “difficult to predict” with different parts of the country recovering more slowly than others, he said.In particular, Mr Ells said he was not happy with the customer experience at some of the company’s locations, of which there are more than 2,100.“While the majority of our restaurants are running well, some are not delivering a terrific guest experience,” said Mr Ells.Failure to please returning customers could “needlessly slow” its recovery from illness outbreaks linked to its stores, and disrupt the brand loyalty that it is hoping to cultivate, said Mr Ells.He said the company was focused “relentlessly” on creating “an excellent dining experience” at its locations, and has already made moves to improve operations at locations in cities such as New York and Boston.Mr Ells underscored in his comments how much ground Chipotle has left to make up after third-quarter results that showed same-store sales had declined 21.9 per cent on a year-on-year basis in the third quarter.The company said at the time that it expected to pare its losses in the coming months and to return to single-digit growth by next year.Chipotle has been in the spotlight in recent months after Pershing Square Capital Management, the hedge fund run by billionaire Bill Ackman, disclosed it had taken a 9.9 per cent stake in the company.The fund is expected to push for corporate governance changes and operational improvements.Compared with a year ago, Chipotle’s shares have lost a third of their value. On Tuesday, they fell a further 7.6 per cent to $366.37.By the close of trading, the major US stock indices were stronger with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.2 per cent to 19,251.78. The S&P 500 advanced 0.3 per cent to 2,212.23 and the Nasdaq Composite gained 0.5 per cent to 5,333.00.Meanwhile shares in athletic apparel maker Nike were pulling up short, declining 2.5 per cent after a note from analysts at Cowen and Company questioned whether the company is facing “potentially peak market share”.While it remains a “gold standard in global retail” in terms of its consistency, reach and historical growth, Cowen analysts said they expected Nike to face more pressure in coming months from rivals Under Armour and Adidas, which are increasingly favoured by millennial men and women aged 18-34.The slippage among youthful shoppers is particularly concerning because they are the “most important purchasers of athletic apparel and sneakers” and leading trendsetters, according to Cowen analysts.While the company’s direct-to-consumer website and owned stores are still performing impressively, wholesale — which accounts for more than two-thirds of its business — are seen as facing the strongest potential headwinds and competition, the note said.While Nike still remains one of the best regarded athletic apparel companies in the world, it recently spooked investors by announcing that future orders — a forward-looking indicator of sales — had risen just 1 per cent in its biggest unit, North America, as of August 31, missing expectations for a 5 per cent rise.Compared with a year ago, Nike shares have declined about 23.6 per cent to trade at $50.57 on Tuesday.

Titular: Chipotle shares slide after CEO expresses concerns about recovery
Texto: Chipotle has spent the year trying to bounce back from a food-safety scare, and the fast-casual burrito chain’s shares slid 7 per cent on Tuesday after its chief executive said that he was “not satisfied with the rate of recovery”.During an investor conference on Tuesday, Chipotle chief executive Steve Ells called 2016 the most challenging year ever for the company. While sales have started to creep back, they remain “uneven” and “difficult to predict,” with different parts of the country recovering more quickly, or slowly, than others, he said during remarks at Barclays Eat, Sleep Play – It’s Not All Discretionary conference in New York.In particular, Mr Ells said he was not happy with the customer experience at some of the company’s locations, of which there are more than 2,100. “While the majority of our restaurants are running well, some are not delivering a terrific guest experience,” Mr Ells said. Failure to please returning customers could “needlessly slow” its recovery from foodborne-illness outbreaks linked to its stores, Mr Ells said, and shatter the brand loyalty that it is hoping to cultivate.He said that, as a result, the company was focused “relentlessly” on creating “an excellent dining experience” at its locations, and has already moved to improve operations at locations in cities such as New York and Boston.Mr Ells underscored in his comments how much ground Chipotle has left to make up, after third-quarter results that showed same-store sales had declined 21.9 per cent on a year-on-year basis in the third quarter. The company said at the time that it expects to pare its losses in coming months and to return to single-digit growth by next year.Chipotle has been in the spotlight in recent months after Pershing Square Capital Management, the hedge fund run by billionaire Bill Ackman, disclosed it had taken a 9.9 per cent stake in the company. The fund is expected to push for corporate governance changes and operational improvements.Compared to a year ago, Chipotle’s shares have lost a third of their value.

Titular: Chipotle’s woes deepen as it struggles to lure back customers
Texto: Burrito chain Chipotle Mexican Grill on Tuesday showed that it has not yet managed to turn the corner from a food-safety crisis that started nearly a year ago, with same-store sales sliding more than forecast in the third quarter.Same-store sales were down 21.9 per cent in the three-month period ending September 30, the company announced after the market closed. Although it has staunched the rate of bleeding compared to the first two quarters of 2016, the decline in same-store sales was steeper than the 18.7 per cent slide predicted by analysts.Revenue also failed to meet analysts’ target, coming in at $1.04bn, compared to analysts’ predictions of $1.09bn and down 14.8 per cent from the third quarter of 2015.Chipotle blamed the continued slide on falling same-store sales as well as deferral of $11.5m in revenue related to unredeemed awards from its Chiptopia customer loyalty programme. Comparable restaurant transactions, meanwhile, were down 15.2 per cent in the past quarter, primarily due to the lower number of transactions per restaurant and cheques that were smaller than average, the company said.Third-quarter net income was $7.8m, equating to $0.27 per diluted share and well below the $45.6m in profit and $1.55 per share predicted by analysts. The company said profits were dented by a deferral it took in connection with the unredeemed Chiptopia rewards and an impairment charge connected to its ShopHouse Southeast Asian Kitchen restaurants.Chipotle is still working to rebuild sales after customers were rattled by foodborne-illness outbreaks linked to its stores, which have sickened 485 people in 13 US states. It is also fighting against a generally sluggish environment for fast-casual restaurants.“After successfully implementing an industry leading food safety programme, and as our marketing efforts are driving more people to our restaurants, it is critical that we are prepared to delight customers on every visit,” said co-chief executive Monty Moran.Pershing Square Capital Management, the hedge fund run by billionaire Bill Ackman recently revealed a 9.9 per cent stake in the company, saying it believed its stock was undervalued and an “attractive investment.”Chipotle said it still expects to reach the high end of its projected range of 220-235 new restaurant openings by the end of the year, and to pare comparable restaurant sale losses to the single-digits in the coming quarter, and to be back in the black with single-digit growth next year. The company’s shares, which have fallen 37 per cent from a year earlier, were down another 2 per cent in after-hours trading.

Titular: Chipotle shares jump as Ackman builds 9.9% stake
Subtitular: Investors hope billionaire activist will help rejuvenate beleagueredburrito chain
Texto: Dissident investors in Chipotle welcomed Pershing Square’s investment in the burrito chain on Wednesday, as the company’s shares jumped following disclosure from the activist group that it had built a 9.9 per cent stake.CtW Investment Group, which represents union pension funds, said it hoped billionaire Bill Ackman’s Pershing Square would act as a “catalyst” for a turnround at the company, adding that the board “desperately needs new leadership” including an independent chair to ensure accountability to shareholders.“The board ignored its shareholders for too long, and we hope Ackman will be a catalyst for a strategic turnround that creates long-term value, not just a push for financial engineering that boosts the stock price for the short term,” said Dieter Waizenegger, executive director at CtW.Chipotle’s shares gained 5.9 per cent to $438.45 on Wednesday in New York, still 42.1 per cent below its peak last August before a food scare that sickened more than 400 people across 13 US states sent its sales into a tailspin.Chipotle had its first phone conversation with Mr Ackman on Wednesday and the company expects to meet him directly soon.Pershing Square, which is nursing losses from its investment in drugmaker Valeant, is expected to push for corporate governance changes and operational improvements, rather than a financial restructuring or a sale of the company.In contrast to some activist campaigns, which begun with hostile letters detailing managerial failings, Mr Ackman’s regulatory filing was notable for its praise of the company, which it said had “a strong brand, differentiated offering, enormous growth opportunity, and visionary leadership”. It added that the company’s stock was undervalued.The move by Pershing adds a twist in Chipotle’s slow story of recovery, where comparable store sales, a key metric for measuring growth, are still dropping double digits on a quarterly basis, despite moves by management to introduce loyalty programmes, such as Chiptopia, and better food safety procedures to lure back consumers.Chipotle said in a statement late on Tuesday that it welcomed the investment and confidence Pershing had in the company. But analysts did not greet the news as some sort of panacea for the company.“We see no quick fix to what Chipotle really needs — a revitalisation of top-line [growth],” said Morgan Stanley analyst John Glass. “But the presence of a large and vocal investor may provide management more incentive to hasten their turnround efforts, which appear to have stalled, and could cause the shorts to cover, at least for now.”Mr Ackman has experience investing in quick service restaurant chains, including McDonald’s and Burger King.And following a shareholder protest earlier this year over the board’s response to the company’s crisis, there is an empty seat on the board.RJ Hottovy, an analyst at Morningstar, said: “At minimum, Ackman could propose board changes. [The board] has been a valid concern.” He added that he expects proposals for new restaurant formats — possibly drive-thrus — permanent loyalty programmes and “some sort of franchising”, as well as adding debt to the company.Some analysts were baffled by Pershing’s investment in the burrito fast casual chain. The team at Stifel, led by Paul Westra, headlined its note to clients: “Pershing Position Creates Excellent Selling Opportunity”.Howard Penney, managing director at Hedgeye Risk Management, said he was surprised that Pershing had invested ahead of the outcome of a criminal investigation.

Titular: Bill Ackman’s Pershing reveals Chipotle stake
Subtitular: Hedge fund expected to push for operational improvements as chain recovers from food safety problems
Texto: Pershing Square Capital Management, the hedge fund run by billionaire investor Bill Ackman, on Tuesday unveiled a stake in Chipotle and said it plans to pursue talks with the US burrito chain.The hedge fund is expected to push for corporate governance changes and operational improvements as Chipotle recovers from food safety problems, rather than a financial restructuring or a sale of the company.In contrast to some activist campaigns, which are begun with hostile letters detailing managerial failings, Mr Ackman’s regulatory filing was notable for its praise of the company, which it said had “a strong brand, differentiated offering, enormous growth opportunity, and visionary leadership”.Pershing said that it had taken a 9.9 per cent stake in the group and that it believed the stock was “undervalued and is an attractive investment”.Chipotle said: “We welcome their investment, and appreciate the confidence they’ve expressed in our brand.”The company, once a Wall Street high-flyer, came under pressure last year after a string of food safety scares that affected more than 400 people across 13 US states sent its sales and stock price reeling. It closed on Tuesday at $414.07, from a record high of $757.77 in August 2015.Same-store sales, a key metric, plummeted 23.6 per cent in the three months ending in June, the third straight quarter of declines that halted a streak of increases that even stretched through the 2008 financial crisis.Co-chief executive Steve Ells has vowed to turn the chain round by bolstering food safety procedures and launching programmes aimed at getting customers back through its doors. For instance, Chipotle unveiled a loyalty scheme called Chiptopia and launched back-to-school specials aimed at parents and students.Shareholders have raised concerns over the quality of directors’ response to the crisis, however, and staged one of the largest protest votes at a US company this year when more than 30 per cent withheld support for the re-election of the chair of the board’s governance committee. In response, the company said it is searching for at least one new board member.Chipotle shares jumped 5.8 per cent to $438 in after-hours trading.

Titular: Boeing shares slide on Dreamliner charge
Subtitular: Chipotle higher after hinting at recovery
Texto: Boeing shares fell on Friday after the blue-chip aerospace group said it will take a $2.1bn second-quarter charge related to its Dreamliner programme and other initiatives it has had to reassess.The Chicago-based group said that it had decided not to invest in refurbishing two 787 test aircraft that it produced in 2009 and have remained unsold. As a result, Boeing said it would take an $847m charge and shift the expense to its research and development unit.In addition, Boeing said that it planned to continue making 747-8 aircraft at a rate of 0.5 a month, and no longer increase the rate to 1 a month in 2019 to “account for current and anticipated weakness in the air cargo market”. That move will prompt Boeing to take an $814m charge that “reflects a lower estimated total of 747-8 freighter aircraft to be produced in the programme accounting quantity and lower estimated revenues on future aircraft sales”.Finally, the company will also recognise a $393m charge related to its KC-46 tanker, an aircraft that will be used by the US Air Force for mid-air refuelling of its air assets. The programme had run into technical challenges that also prompted Boeing to take a charge in the first quarter.The company is due to report its full second-quarter earnings figures on July 27.After falling more than 1.5 per cent at one stage on Friday, Boeing’s shares recovered, closing little changed at $133.45, bringing their year-to-date decline to 7.7 per cent.Elsewhere, Chipotle shares were in the black after the US burrito chain hinted at a nascent recovery from a painful sales decline sparked by a food safety scare that formally came to an end in February.Same-store sales, an important metric for food chains, were down 21 per cent in July compared with the prior year, said Steve Ells, co-chief executive. While the figure highlights the struggle the group, once a fast food darling, faces in attempting to right the ship, it points to a recovery from the 23.6 per cent same-store sales decline in the quarter to June 30, and the 29.7 per cent decline in the period before that.Mr Ells also said he was “optimistic” that the new Chiptopia rewards programme would “encourage more guests to visit our restaurants and that this will help lead to a sustained higher sales recovery”.Wall Street analysts offered a mixed assessment of Chipotle’s recovery attempt.“Chipotle’s issues remain unchanged and despite the progress management has made with its supply chain and with its efforts to aggressively reach out to its customers (through marketing, promotions and a loyalty programme), sales traction has been slower to materialise than the company has hoped for,” said Brett Levy of Deutsche Bank.However, Jeff Farmer at Wells Fargo noted that the earnings release and the conference call with executives “offered far more bullish than bearish commentary [and] guidance on several key areas of investor debate”.Chipotle’s shares rose 5.8 per cent on Friday to $442.30, but are still down 39 per cent over the past 12 months.At the close of trade, the S&P 500 reached a new high, up 0.5 per cent at 2,175, the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.3 per cent to 18,570.9 and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.5 per cent to 5,100.2.

Titular: Chipotle shares slide after restaurant closure
Subtitular: Fast-food chain’s shares have declined 26% since the beginning of last year
Texto: Chipotle shares suffered a blow on Wednesday after the Mexican fast-food restaurant said a Massachusetts restaurant was temporarily closed after it learnt that four of its employees had fallen sick.News that Chipotle’s restaurant in Billerica, Massachusetts, was closed for a “full sanitisation” after employees got sick pushed shares in the Denver-based company 3.5 per cent lower to $506.50. None of the employees worked while they were sick, the company said.“Any employees who reported feeling ill will be held out of the restaurant until they fully recover,” a company spokesman said in a statement.Chipotle has worked to win back customers since it came under scrutiny late last year after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said it was investigating an E. coli outbreak linked to its restaurants. The company’s shares were rattled further after a norovirus outbreak made students in Boston ill.The food-safety scares triggered its first year-on-year decline in quarterly sales since at least 2006, and sparked a federal probe.Chipotle shares have declined 26 per cent since the beginning of last year.Elsewhere, shares in Darden Restaurants advanced 3.6 per cent to $66.93, after the company behind Olive Garden and LongHorn Steakhouse provided an upbeat profit outlook for its fiscal third quarter and named a new chief financial officer.The Florida-based company said it expected adjusted earnings per share from continuing operations in the range of $1.18 to $1.21, above analysts’ estimates for $1.06 a share.Meanwhile, same-store sales are estimated to increase 6 per cent for the quarter, which is partly affected by the timing of the Thanksgiving holiday. On a comparable calendar basis they are expected to rise 4 per cent.The company also said Ricardo Cardenas had been appointed chief financial officer effective immediately, replacing Jeffrey Davis. Mr Cardenas recently served as chief strategy officer for Darden.Activist investor Starboard Value took control of the company last year with 12 seats on the board. Under Starboard, Darden has made efforts to lower expenses and revamp its menu at Olive Garden in an effort to attract more customers.Groupon shares fell more than 10 per cent to $4.11, after analysts at UBS downgraded the US coupon company to “sell” from “neutral” and maintained their $3.20 price target.While Groupon has showed signs of progress “there is still a long road ahead in strengthening the company’s positioning in the local ad and/or local ecommerce market,” said Eric Sheridan, an analyst at UBS.Moreover, he noted that companies such as Google and Facebook are stepping up efforts to “capture local ad dollars” and that “in light of Amazon’s increasing efforts in the same-day delivery space, we believe the benefit of a ‘local’ marketplace is diminished over the longer term”.Mr Sheridan also downgraded shares of review website Yelp to “sell” from “neutral” sending shares of the review website 3 per cent lower to $20.47.At the close, the S&P 500 was 0.5 per cent higher at 1,989, the Dow Jones Industrial Average had climbed 0.2 per cent to 17,000 and the Nasdaq Composite had risen 0.6 per cent to 4,674.A rally in oil prices propelled energy shares 1.5 per cent higher, with the sector leading the benchmark S&P 500.mamta.badkar@ft.comTwitter: @mamtabadkar

Titular: Chipotle shares slip on sell call
Subtitular: Bank says US burrito chain at risk of ‘permanent’ loss of customers after food-safety crisis
Texto: Chipotle Mexican Grill slipped lower on Tuesday after Deutsche Bank advised selling the stock over concerns the US burrito chain could face a “permanent” loss of customers following its recent food-safety crisis.A string of scares linked to Chipotle last year that left 500 people ill caused the company’s stock price to collapse by more than half from a record high in August 2015.But the shares have since rebounded by about 30 per cent from their low on January 16, as US food regulators said a duo of E.coli outbreaks had ended and Chipotle launched a marketing campaign to strengthen customer loyalty.However, Deutsche isn’t so certain the once high-flying chain is out of the woods. “Ongoing challenges do not bode well for a swift and robust recovery,” Karen Short, an analyst at Deutsche, wrote in a report.Ms Short said she remained “concerned with the potential permanent loss of customers [from changes in brand perception or increased competition] as a result of these issues”.Deutsche Bank is the only big Wall Street investment bank that has a “sell” rating on the stock, Bloomberg data show.Chipotle’s shares dipped 0.3 per cent to $524.54 and are down 21.8 per cent over the past 12 months.Meanwhile, Home Depot shares rose after it unveiled a bigger-than-expected rise in quarterly sales and profits as the US home improvement retailer benefited from a robust housing market.The Atlanta-based company said sales climbed 9.5 per cent on a year-on-year basis in the quarter through to January 31 to $21bn. Meanwhile, earnings rose to $1.5bn, or $1.17 a share, from $1.4bn, or $1.05 a share, in the same quarter the previous year.Adam Samson reports on US burrito chain Chipotle’s food-safety woes and interviews a restaurant-industry consultant on steps companies can take to avoid similar issues.Wall Street had expected profits of $1.10 a share on sales of $20.4bn.The blue-chip company also said it expected revenues to rise 5.1 per cent — 6 per cent in the current fiscal year, topping forecasts.Home Depot has benefited from a strong housing market that has lured consumers who have been skittish about spending on items such as clothing and electronics to invest in home repairs and upgrades.The group climbed 1.4 per cent to $124.53, trimming larger gains amid a pullback in the broader market.Energy shares, meanwhile, fell sharply after Saudi Arabia’s influential oil minister warned the oil producer was “not banking on [supply] cuts”.The comments from Ali al-Naimi throw cold water on hopes that big producers may act to stabilise the price of crude amid a glut of global supply.The S&P 500 energy index dropped 3.2 per cent as US crude oil prices slid 4.6 per cent to $31.87 a barrel.Among the energy laggards was exploration and production company Marathon Oil, which fell 6.1 per cent to $7.03 a share. ExxonMobil, the biggest US energy company, declined 1.4 per cent to $81.23.At the close, the S&P 500 had fallen 1.3 per cent to 1,921.3, the Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 1.1 per cent to 16,431.8 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 1.5 per cent to 4,503.6.The broad decline for Wall Street came in stark comparison to the rally in the previous session. The energy sector logged the heaviest losses on Tuesday, but every other big S&P 500 sector, bar utilities, was in the red as well.

Titular: Chipotle founder Steve Ells forced to rework recipe for success
Subtitular: Co-chief is confident his burrito chain can recover from food safety concerns
Texto: Steve Ells, Chipotle’s founder and co-chief executive, built his Mexican burrito chain into a company with a $14.4bn market value under the banner “food with integrity”, as he pursued the use of humanely and sustainably produced ingredients.But Chipotle’s integrity when it comes to food safety was called into question last year after outbreaks of E. coli, norovirus and salmonella at Chipotle restaurants across 13 states left hundreds of customers ill — with some being hospitalised. This week, the company posted its first year-on-year drop in quarterly sales in at least a decade.For Mr Ells, who once boasted of being “the best in the world” at sourcing and cooking “really great ingredients”, the challenge ahead is stark — shares in his company are down nearly 40 per cent since August.Once dubbed “the burrito billionaire” — his stake in Chipotle is now worth less than a fifth of that — Mr Ells took a circuitous route into fast food.After studying art history at University of Colorado and attending the Culinary Institute of America, he initially sought work in fine dining as a sous chef under Jeremiah Tower at Stars restaurant.He dreamt of opening his own upmarket establishment, but decided to start smaller, with a simple restaurant that could serve as a “cash cow” for a grander project. Taking inspiration from San Francisco’s taquerias, he borrowed money from his father, a pharmaceuticals executive, and launched Chipotle in 1993.His burritos concept — providing quality ingredients in a fast-casual restaurant — proved so popular that 22 years have passed and he has never opened that upmarket restaurant. The chain eventually won financial backing from McDonald’s and then it listed in New York a decade ago. There are now more than 2,000 Chipotles across the US, with a small number in Canada and Europe as well.Mr Ells has also started an Asian-themed chain called Shophouse and is expanding a pizza chain — Pizzeria Locale — which has the same concept as Chipotle — take the base, choose the toppings and watch it being made as you queue.“We’re having more of an impact on the way people eat than I ever would have had if I’d stuck with my original plan,” he told a Denver magazine two years ago.Mr Ells, 49, struck a humbler note this week, describing Chipotle’s fourth quarter as “without question the most challenging in our history”.Chipotle’s E. coli outbreak has been declared over, but the company is co-operating with a federal criminal investigation. It also faces civil lawsuits and frightened customers.“It has been our aim to serve our guests food that is safe, delicious and wholesome, but the events of the last few months have shown us that we need to do better,” he said.Chipotle is completely reworking its food safety measures, but there are questions over Mr Ells’ communication strategy. Although the company responded to separate instances of E. coli, norovirus and salmonella in the third quarter of last year, it failed to announce a comprehensive response until November, after a multi-state outbreak of E. coli.“It’s really shallow to have communicated the way they did,” said Darin Detwiler, senior policy co-ordinator at Stop Foodborne Illness.Mr Ells and his team face an enormous task as they seek to woo back customers, at a time when monthly sales had already started to slow.Karen Short, an analyst at Deutsche Bank, wrote: “This situation is unprecedented — no concept has been so loved and so abandoned.”But Mr Ells told analysts he was confident: “With our enhanced food safety programme, we are poised to emerge stronger than ever before.”

Titular: Chipotle shares burnt by earnings warning for current quarter
Subtitular: US energy stocks outperform as oil prices jump
Texto: Chipotle fell on Wednesday after the embattled US burrito chain warned it may not earn a profit in the current quarter and said an official investigation into a string of food-safety issues is broader than initially thought.Denver-based Chipotle posted its first year-on-year drop in quarterly sales since at least 2006 in the fourth quarter as customers responded to an E. coli outbreak linked to its restaurants that surfaced in early November. The E. coli issue was part of a wider series of six outbreaks that made 487 people sick last year.The company, led by Steve Ells, has vowed to become an industry leader in food safety and is launching a big marketing push aimed at getting customers back through its doors.However, those efforts will come at a higher price than some analysts forecast. Chipotle said in a conference call late on Tuesday that it is likely to break even in the current quarter, compared with Wall Street estimates of profits of $1.95 a share.The chain, which is famous for its Mexican-inspired eats that are advertised as fresher than offerings at fast food rivals, is also facing an investigation into its handling of food safety issues. The US Attorney for the Central District of California has issued a subpoena for Chipotle to “produce documents and information related to company-wide food safety matters dating back to January 1, 2013”, the company said in a statement.Chipotle’s shares dropped 2.9 per cent to $461.74 on Wednesday and have tumbled 35 per cent over the past 12 months.Still, many Wall Street analysts remain bullish on the stock: 40.6 per cent of analysts surveyed by Bloomberg have a “buy” rating on Chipotle. Jeffrey Farmer, an analyst at Wells Fargo, actually increased his rating on Chipotle to “outperform” from “market perform” on Wednesday.Mr Farmer said in a note to clients that history has shown sales growth often returns 12-15 months after a food-safety incident.“While the E.coli pushback has been severe, Chipotle has among the most fervent customer bases in the industry,” he said, noting he sees like-for-like sales improving “more quickly than expected” in the second half of this year.Elsewhere, energy shares outperformed as the price of crude oil raced higher. US crude jumped 8.6 per cent to $32.46 a barrel as the US dollar slid 1.7 per cent against a basket of global currencies. A weaker US currency is generally bullish for the price of dollar-denominated commodities.Murphy Oil, an exploration and production company, jumped 10.5 per cent to $19.26 a share. Kinder Morgan, a large pipeline operator, rallied 6.5 per cent to $15.60 a share. Meanwhile, ExxonMobil, the biggest US oil company, climbed 5.2 per cent to $78.47.On the other side of the spectrum, banks came under further pressure after weak data on the US services sector once again pushed back expectations for when the Federal Reserve will next increase interest rates.The S&P 500 rose 0.5 per cent to 1,912.53, the Dow Jones Industrial Average 1.1 per cent to 16,336.66 and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.3 per cent to 4,504.24.

Titular: Chipotle’s food safety concerns turn viral
Subtitular: US restaurant chain’s link to illness outbreaks sparks federal probe and roils share price
Texto: Chipotle Mexican Grill, the US restaurant chain that has built a $4bn-a-year empire on burritos and guacamole, is facing a crisis that has struck at its core: a string of food-safety scares that have hit sales hard, sparked a federal probe and roiled its stock market value.The company has been linked to at least six outbreaks of illnesses last year that caused sickness in 485 people in 13 US states, according to an analysis of data collected from local, state and federal health authorities.Linda Harris, a professor of food safety at the University of California, said the number of outbreaks at Chipotle in one year was “mind boggling”.The first three food-safety issues initially did little to dent bullish sentiment in Chipotle. The stock reached a record closing high of $757.77 on August 5, a huge increase from its $22 initial public offering price in 2006, valuing the Mexican-style food chain at $23.6bn.But in early November, a far broader scare hit the headlines: an outbreak of a strain of E.coli that affected 39 people, most of whom ate at one of several Chipotle restaurants in Washington and Oregon.The food-safety woes escalated as the year came to a close, and this time investors, and diners, took notice.When asked if Chipotle management feels it should have tackled the food-safety issues more quickly, a company spokesperson said: “It is natural to second-guess practices after incidents like these, and no one is taking a harder look at what we are doing than we are.”Chipotle said last week that same-store sales tumbled 30 per cent in December from the same month in 2014, and warned “future sales trends may be significantly influenced by further developments”.Chipotle’s stock has dropped nearly 53.3 per cent and shed $10.9bn in market value since its August peak amid uncertainty over how long it will take for the company to get to grips with the issue.The chain also disclosed last week a federal grand jury subpoena regarding a criminal investigation related to its California store that faced a Norovirus outbreak.Chipotle now faces a battle to win back investor confidence and restore its image among customers.Founded in 1993, Chipotle has benefited from shifting consumer appetites away from traditional fast-food to options that are seen as fresher and healthier.It has become known for its simple menu of burritos, tacos and other Mexican-style food served with an array of add-ons, like guacamole and salsa, all made from what the company calls “better ingredients”.Customers can peer into open kitchens, where staff members use “classic cooking techniques” to whip up big batches of food.Until recently, the model has worked: same-store sales rose every year in the decade up to 2014, according to data from Bloomberg.
